notesStmt.note: By William Bradshaw. Includes: Ames, William. A manudiction for Mr. Robinson.

"The unreasonablenesse of the separation" answers STC 14660: Francis Johnson's "Certayne reasons and arguments proving that it is not lawfull to heare the present ministerie of the Church of England". "A manudiction for Mr. Robinson" answers: John Robinson's "Of religious communion private, & publique" (stc 21115)--Folger Shakespeare Library catalogue.
"The unreasonableness of the separation" has anonymous preface, identified as by William Ames in STC 3533. "A manudicition for Mr. Robinson" is answered by STC 21111--STC.
Reproduction of the original in the Emmanuel College (University of Cambridge). Library.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE VNREASONABLENESSE of the ≈øeparation.
Made apparant, by an examination of Mr. Iohn≈øons pretended rea≈øons, publi≈øhed an. 1608. Wherby hee laboureth to iu≈øtifie his ≈øchisme from the Church A≈ø≈øemblies of England.

q.p: The end of the commandement is charitie, out of a pure heart, and of a good con≈øcience, and of fayth vnfayned. From which ≈øome hauing ≈øwa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed, haue turned a ≈øide vnto vaine Jangling, de≈øiring to bee teachers of the Law, vnder≈øtanding neither what they ≈øay, nor wherof they affirme.

div.p: AT DORT, Printed by George Waters. 1614.

div.head: TO THE WELL meaning Reader.
div.p: THink not euill, if thou meane≈øt well, wee intend not to in≈øult over him that is downe, or to pur≈øue a man that is flying of him≈øelfe: but to lend him a hand that knoweth not well which way to take. Mr. Iohn≈øon in deed, is rather to bee pitied, then much oppo≈øed: wee need but ≈øtand ≈øtill as lookers on: hee falleth willingly on his owne ≈øword but that his fall may bee a ri≈øing againe, not onely to him≈øelf, but to others al≈øo, both armour-bearers & followers of his: it was iudged nece≈ø≈øarie, to guide them a litle while their heads are dizzy, & bring them fairly from of the bogge they haue ≈øtood on.

It is not Mr. John≈øon that is dealt with alone
for change the name onely, and put in Mr. Ain≈øworth, or any ≈øuch: them≈øelues will not ≈øay but the rea≈øons are theirs, and the an≈øwer, to them, as well as to him. Jt may bee that they hauing le≈ø≈øe acquaintance with logicall formes of di≈øpute, will looke for large di≈øcour≈øe, or heaped quotations out of ≈øcripture. But rea≈øon will tell them, that many words doe rather hide them vntie the knot of a ≈øyllogi≈øme: and much quoting may proue ≈øome-thing, but an≈øwereth not directly to any thing. Now the wrighters meaning was, not to gather proofes, but to poynt at the weakne≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch as the≈øe men haue gathered. Read therfore with vnder≈øtanding, and learn a mean betwixt All and Nothing.

div.head: THE MAINE CONclu≈øion of Mr. John≈øons Rea≈øons, as it is propounded by him≈øelf, is this, That it is not lawfull to heare or haue any ≈øpiritual communion wit the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church, A≈ø≈øemblies of Englande.
div.p: WHich hee laboureth to proue. 1. By Rea≈øons (as hee fancieth) drawne from Scripture, and other Te≈øtimonies.

2. By Argumentes collected from the writeinges of them, whom hee ≈øtileth (in di≈ødaine) forward Preachers. And this hee performeth as far as the remainders of his logick skill will giue him leaue, in moode and figure. But the figure for the mo≈øte part is of his owne ≈øhapeing, ≈øuch as neuer came forth of any logick Schooles: yet feing the truth hee oppo≈øeth receaueth noe di≈øadvantage therby. I can (for my owne parte) be content that his Syllogi≈ømes ≈øtil retaine tho≈øe formes and figures, that hee hath put vpon them, and ≈øpare the labour of Tran≈ølating them into nue. And ≈øo without any further expence of wordes, I come to the Examination of the fir≈øt ≈øort of Rea≈øons.

div.head: THE FIRST SORTE OF Rea≈øons from the Scriptures and other Te≈øtimonies Examined.

item.hi: All are bound in the wor≈øhip of God to heare and communicate onely with that ministery which Christ hath giuen, and ≈øet in his Church for that worke.
But the pre≈øent Ministery of the Church A≈ø≈øemblies of England, is not that which Christ hath giuen, and ≈øet in his Church for the worke of his Ministery.
Therfore it is not lawfull for any in the wor≈øhip of God to heare or communicate with the pre≈øent Ministery of the Church A≈ø≈øemblies of England.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: Not to contend about the Propo≈øition. I deny the A≈ø≈øumption: and affirme, That the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies (how ≈øoever it may in ≈øome particuler parts of the execution, happely be defectiue in ≈øome places) is, (for the ≈øub≈øtance thereof) that very ≈øame Mini≈øtery which Chri≈øt hath ≈øet in his Church for the worke of his mini≈øtery whether it bee the mini≈øtery of tho≈øe which hee calleth the forward Preachers, or of tho≈øe which being qualified according to the true inteÃÑt of the lawe, do ≈øub≈øcribe, and conforme according to the laws of the State.

item.hi: The Ministery which Christ hath giuen, and ≈øet in his Church, is, of Apostles, Prophets, Euangelists, Pastors, and Teachers ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11.12.
But the pre≈øent Ministery of the Church of England is none of the≈øe ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11.12.
Therefore it is not the Mini≈øtery which Christ hath giuen and ≈øet in his Church.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: The pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church of England (1. of the Church A≈ø≈øemblies of England) is the Mini≈øtery of Pa≈øtors and Teachers.

item.hi: The pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church of England is of Prelates, Priestes and Deacons.
But nether Prelates, Prie≈øtes, nor Deacons of that Church, are Pastors or Teachers ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11.12.
Therefore it is none of tho≈øe ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11.12.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: I denye both Prepo≈øition and A≈ø≈øumption. For 1. Though our Preletes, doe ≈øometimes voluntarily and occa≈øionnally performe the ≈øame worke and ≈øeruice in ≈øome of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies, which our ordinary Mini≈øters doe, yet their Prelaticall or Epi≈øcopall office or Mini≈øtery is not the proper Mini≈øtery of any of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies. But (in the intent of our lawes) their propre Mini≈øtery con≈øi≈øts in over≈øeeing the Mini≈øters and Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies.

2. Though ≈øometimes our Mini≈øters be called PRIESTS and DEACONS yet the MINISTERY vnder tho≈øe names a≈ø≈øigned vnto them, and which they exerci≈øe is not the proper and e≈ø≈øentiall Mini≈øtery of either Prie≈øtes or Deacons; but of Pa≈øtors and Teachers: Soe that they are onely in aequivocation, and name, or Metaphorically Prie≈øtes and Deacons: But really Pa≈øtors and Teachers, and therfore ≈øuch Prie≈øts and Deacons, may bee, and indeede and truth are ≈øuch Pa≈øtors and Teachers as are ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11.12.

item.hi: The Prepo≈øition is manifest.
1. The Law of that Church admitteth not any other Mini≈øtery, but that of their Prelacie Priesthoode and Deaconry, receaued amongst them ≈øelues or from the Papistes.

2. Their Con≈øtitution is ≈øuch as all the Mini≈øters of that Church must bee Priests or Deacons, and thei≈øe al≈øo either in a Superior degree as the Prelates, Arch. Bi≈øhops Suffraganes &c. or in an inferior, as Par≈øons, Vicars, Stipendaries, Chaplins.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
1. It is not nece≈ø≈øary that the Mini≈øtery of a contrey or nation ≈øhould be alwaies ≈øuch as the law e≈øtabli≈øheth or admitteth: The Mini≈øtery (at lea≈øt in ≈øome places) may be good though the law in generall ≈øhould admit and e≈øtabli≈øhe ≈øuch a one as is bad: as on the contrarye ≈øide, the mini≈øtery may at ≈øome times, and in ≈øome ca≈øes be bad, though the laws admit, & e≈øtabli≈øh neuer ≈øoe good; for the Gouernors of Churches and common wealths who haue the di≈øpen≈øation of lawes, may in their Chri≈øtian wi≈øedome, and moderation permitt a mini≈øtery in
≈øundrie re≈øpects different from that which the laws require; yea and our owne Gouernors in fact haue permitted the mini≈øtery of ≈øome, who neuer receiued ordination, either from Papi≈øts or them≈øelues. And hee cannot be ignorant but that ≈øome by connivencie are yet ≈øuffred in ≈øome points of their mini≈øtery to ≈øwerue from ≈øome ob≈øervances which the lawes require. The Argument therefore will not follow, from the qualitie of the mini≈øtery, except hee can proue that our Mini≈øtery is in all our A≈ø≈øemblies, in all re≈øpects aim≈øwerable to our lawes.

2. The Pree≈øthood which the law admitteth is not called Sacerdotius but Presbyteratus, and the Prie≈øts are not called Sacerdotes or ≈øacrificers but Presbyters, (as ≈øufficiently appeares by our orders in Latin.) Therefore the Law doth not intende any true and proper Prie≈øthood but onely boroweth the name to expre≈ø≈øe an office of another kinde.

3. To bee Per≈øons, Vicars, Stipendaries, Chaplins, &c. is not to haue a diuers kind of Prie≈øthood or deaconry, or Mini≈øtery (as hee fooli≈øhly conceiteth:) onely varietie of Tytles is giuen to the ≈øame kind of Mini≈øtery, in diuers per≈øons, in re≈øpect only of a diuers kinde of maintenaunce or dependance, for Par≈øons are ≈øuch as haue all tythes in kinde; Vicars ≈øuch as haue only the ≈ømaller Tyths, the other being impropriated by the Magi≈øtrate for other purpo≈øes; Stipendaries are ≈øuch as are maintained by the voluntary Contribution of their Churches or by ≈øome ≈øuch like meanes. Chaplins are ≈øuch as depend vpon great men; The Mini≈øtery of all which (If they duly execute the ≈øame) is one and the ≈øame, even that
(and noe other for ≈øub≈øtance) which is proper to true Pa≈øtors and Teachers.

item.hi: The A≈øsumption is prooued by their 7. Arguments following.

The Pa≈øtors and Teachers ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11. haue their offices, callings, admini≈øtration and mainetenaunce ordained by Chri≈øt in his Te≈øtamente, Eph. 4.8.11.12. and Rom. 12.7.8. Act. 14.23. and 20.17.28. Heb. 5.4. Col. 4.17, 1. The≈ø. 5, 12.13.14, 1. Pet. 5.1.2.3. Reu. 2. and 3. and 22.18, 1. Cor. 14.1. and 5.4. and 9.14. and 11.23. and 12.28. Gal. 6.6.
But the Prelates, Prie≈øts & Deacons of the Church of England, haue not their offices, Callings, Mini≈øtration and Maintenaunce ordained by Chri≈øt in his Testament.

list.item: Ergo. They are not Pa≈øtors and Teachers ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11.

item.hi: The A≈ø≈øumption appeareth by their Con≈øtitution and practice, in as much as their offices of Prelacie, Prie≈øthood, and Deaconry, their calling, and entraunce, according to their Pontificall, Their choy≈øe of their people, whoe ≈øtand them≈øelues vnder Antichri≈øt, and vn≈øeperated from the worlde, and are noe true vi≈øible Churches of Chri≈øte. Their Ministration by their owne, and other Popi≈øh Canons, Artes Iniunctions, and booke of Common prayer, their maintenaunce by Tyths, Lord≈øhips &c. were neuer ordained by Chri≈øt for his Mini≈øtery, but diriued from Antichri≈øt and his Apo≈øta≈øye, as hath bene proued by vs in diuers treati≈øes.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
1. The Propo≈øition is not true, except hee vnder≈øtand by offices, Callings, and admini≈øtration, the Sub≈øtantial, or E≈ø≈øentiall parts therof. Otherwi≈øe tho≈øe very Pa≈øtors
and Teachers ther ≈øpoken of, may haue diuers acce≈ø≈øary parts of their offices callings and admini≈øtration not ordayned by Chri≈øt in the newe Te≈øtament. Nether is it true, Yf by maintenaunce hee meane any ≈øpeciall kind of maintenaunce. It is to be graunted in generall. That Mini≈øters, are to haue ≈øufficient maintenaunce, and the texts a ledged for that proues noe more, and therfore that which they proue, is nothing to the purpo≈øe; As little to the purpo≈øe are the other Texts, for it will not follow from any force in them, but that there may bee ≈øundry accidents cleauing as parts to the offices, calling, and maintenaunce of true Pa≈øtors, and Teachers, which Chri≈øt neuer ordained.

2. Concerning the A≈ø≈øumption. 1. whether Prelates haue their office, calling &c. ordained by Chri≈øt is be≈øids the pre≈øent que≈øtion. Except M. Iohn≈øon can proue that they are ordinary Mini≈øters of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies; which I am ≈øure hee cannot. 2 Soe many of our Mini≈øters (whoe in the booke of ordination are called Prie≈øts and Deacons) as in all points concerning the ≈øub≈øtaunce of their Mini≈øtery, are qualified according to the intent of the lawes, haue their offices, callings, admini≈øtration and maintenaunce for the ≈øub≈øtaunce therof, ordained by Chri≈øt: And yet I deny not, but ther may be ≈øome accidentall defects, or Superfluityes in and a bout them all; yet ≈øuch as doe or cannot be proued to de≈øtroy the nature and ≈øub≈øtance of any of them.

3. All that is brought to proue the A≈ø≈øumption is falce, and as much if not more controuer≈øal then the A≈ø≈øumption it ≈øelfe. For 1. hee can neuer proue, that either the practis of all our Mini≈øters, is in all things according
to that Con≈øtitution, or their con≈øtitution according to their practis, or either of them an≈øwerable to the ≈øtrict termes of the law in all points. 2. Hee can neuer proue, that either in their con≈øtitution, or practis, or by the law they are in proper ≈øpeech, either Prie≈øts or Deacons; only hee pre≈øumes them to be ≈øuch, becau≈øe through ≈øome libertie of ≈øpeech v≈øed in the lawes, they are termed ≈øuch. Though it ≈øhould bee graunted that our people ≈øtand vnder, ≈øome kinde of ob≈øervances, and offices which in their owne nature, and fir≈øt originall, are in ≈øome kinde Antichri≈øtian; Yet they are of ≈øuch a nature, that divers worthy Martyrs of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, that haue with ≈øtood Antichri≈øt vnto blood, haue ≈øtood vnder as much as wee. And therfore ≈øuch a manner of ≈øtanding vnder Antichri≈øt, cannot be ≈øaid to overthrowe though it may ≈øomwhat ≈øtaine the Mini≈øtery of Chri≈øte. But how≈øoeuer, hee herein ≈øhamefully begs the que≈øtion, in the naked affirming, without any prooffe, That all in this kingdome are vnder Antichri≈øt.

4. Though (for avoyding further controuer≈øie) that ≈øhould be graunted him, that ≈øome parts of our mini≈øtratioÃÑ by the Canons, &c. was neuer ordayned by Chri≈øt. Yet at the lea≈øt the maine principall, and E≈ø≈øentiall parts therof performed according to the Canons and booke a fore≈øaid, are ordayned by Chri≈øt; yea by M. Iohn≈øon him≈øelf. Nether hath hee proued or euer can proue, That that part of our mini≈øtration, by our Canons, and booke a fore≈øaid, which Chri≈øt hath not ordayned (If any ≈øuch bee) is of that nature and qualitie, that it nece≈ø≈øaryly de≈øtroyeth or maketh a nullity of the other parts of their Mini≈øtery, which v≈øe them.

5. Though Tythes and Lord≈øhippes and manners in perticulers, bee not ordayned by Chri≈øt for the maintenaunce of Mini≈øters, yet they are as much ordayned as any other particuler, or ≈øpeciall kind of maintenaunce, It is the will of Chri≈øt that the Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell ≈øhould liue of the Go≈øpell. i. ≈øhould bee manietanied for their Mini≈øtery ≈øake by them to whome they preach the Go≈øpell. But in what particuler manner that maintaynaunce ≈øhould bee ray≈øed, hee hath noe wher defined and therfore left it to the di≈øcretion of Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrates or Churches.

6. Wheras for the proofes of theis maine pointes, hee referreth vs to the generall Tytles of certaine Treati≈øes formerly publi≈øhed, hee might as well ≈øend vs (as they ≈øay) to ≈øeeke a needle in a bottle of hay, and why doth hee not in all other points of this booke, as well as in the is, ≈øend vs to the ≈øaide Treati≈øes? ≈øeeing hee ≈øaith nothing throughout this in effect, that hee hath not all ready ≈øaide in ≈øome one or other of his former bookes.

item.hi: The Mini≈øtery of Pa≈øtors and Teachers ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11.

is the ordinary and perpetuall Mini≈øtery giuen by Christ to his Church, and ≈øuch as the Princes of the Earth nether may nor ever ≈øhall bee able to aboli≈øhe, ≈øeing Chri≈øt hath appoynted it to continue to the end of the worlde.

But the Prelacie Pree≈øthood, and Deaconrye of the Church of England is not the ordinarije and perpetuall Mini≈øtery giuen by Chri≈øt to his Church, but ≈øuch as the Princes of the Earth may and ought to aboli≈øh out of their Dominions. Rev. 17, 16 1. Tim. 2.2. Rom. 13, 4. with 1. Kin. 23.3. deu. 12.2. P≈øa. 72.1.
Therfore the Pree≈øthood Prelacie and deaconrye of the Church of England is not the Ministery of Pa≈øtors and Teachers ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: Idenye the A≈ø≈øumption. Vnder≈øtanding by Prelacie Pree≈øthood and deaconrye, The ordinary Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies again≈øt which hee propounds to him≈øelf to Di≈øpute; And aun≈øwer. That it is the ordinary and perpetuall Mini≈øtery, giuen by Chri≈øt to his Church, and ≈øuch as the Princes of the Earth are bounde by Gods Lawes to maintaine and protect by their Authoritie; And if their bee any corruption in and aboute the ≈øame, which they ought to aboli≈øh that yet they are accidentiall and per≈øonall; and not ≈øoe E≈ø≈øentiall as that they doe Di≈øtroy the Mini≈øtery.

The places of Scripture anexed to the A≈ø≈øumptioÃÑ for the proofe therof, are all abu≈øed and profaned for not on of them doth any way ≈øoe much as colourablye proue either of the Clau≈øes in the A≈ø≈øumption, but only they proue in generall, That the Idolatry and Idolatrious Mini≈øtery of Antechri≈øt is to be aboli≈øhed: Soe that the man in his ≈øymplicitie, takes it as graunted; That our Mini≈øterye is ≈øuch an Idolatrious Mini≈øtery; which is the maine matter in Controuer≈øy, and in effect the generall que≈øtion of his whole booke.

item.hi: The Office of Pa≈øtors and Teachers ordayned by Chri≈øt in his Te≈øtament,
are ≈øuch as did or could ≈øtand, with the offices of the Apo≈øtels, Prophetes and Euangeli≈øts.

list.item:
But the offices of the Prelates, Prie≈øts or deacons of the Church
of England, are not ≈øuch as did, or could ≈øtand, with or vnder the offices of Apostles, Prophets and Euangeli≈øts: which if any deny, let him ≈øhew the Countrary, by the Scriptures; Light hath no fellow≈øhip with darknes; nor Chri≈øt with Antichri≈øt. And ≈øuppo≈øe the Apo≈øtles were a liue in their Per≈øons, and were in England, It were worth the knowing, whether they and the ordinances giuen by them, ≈øhould giue place to the Prelates, and their Canons, and whether they ≈øhould be ≈øuffred to preach, &c. without ≈øub≈øcribing, and conforming. Their Canons vrge all vpon paine of Excommunication ip≈øo facto.

item.hi: Therfore they are not the Pa≈øtors, and Teachers ordained by Chri≈øt in his nue Te≈øtament.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: 1. What a ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe man is this to affirme, That our Mini≈øtery nether did nor could ≈øtand with the offices of the Apo≈øtles &c. and for proofe therof bid vs, If we deny it ≈øhew the contrary by Scriptures. Doth not the burden of prouing by the very lawe of Common Rea≈øon ly vpon the accu≈øer? If I ≈øhould in like manner reproch his Mini≈øtery, & ≈øay it is a Mini≈øtery that ≈øtandeth vpon Sorcery, witch croft and Coniuration and for proofe therof bid him, If hee deny it ≈øhew the countrary by Scripture, were I not worthy at lea≈øt to bee laughed out of the Scholes. This is a ≈øufficient ju≈øtification of our Mini≈øtery; that ≈øuch Malitions aduer≈øaries therof, whoe woulde ≈øeeme ≈øoe expert in the Scriptures; are no better able by Scripture to proue their vnchri≈øtian accu≈øation.

2. It is true, that light hath noe follow≈øhip with darknes, nor Chri≈øt with Antichri≈øt. Yet ther is no light in men in this
life, but it is mingled with ≈øome darkne≈ø≈øe; and the be≈øt Chri≈øtians that are, or euer haue bene ≈øince the Apo≈øtles times, may be infected with ≈øome points of Antichri≈øtiani≈øme. Many of the late Martyrs ≈øince the revealing of Antichri≈øt, were worthy lights, and renoumed Chri≈øtians, and yet the light of many of them, was mingled with more darkne≈ø≈øe, and their Chri≈øtianitie with more Antichri≈øtiani≈øme, then can be founde in our Mini≈øtery.

3. Our Bi≈øhops haue as good rea≈øon, to make the like ≈øuppo≈øition again≈øt him, and as much worthy the inquirie that were, if the Apo≈øtles, &c. were a liue now in their owne Per≈øons where hee liueth, and ≈øhould profe≈ø≈øe the Church A≈ø≈øemblies in Englande to be true Churches, and their Mini≈øtery in generall to be a lawfull Mini≈øtery, and their wor≈øhip for ≈øub≈øtaunce to bee a true wor≈øhip, whether M. Iohn≈øon and his Church would ≈øuffer them to be ≈øoe much as priuate members, of their Society, much more to preach, &c.

4. Though our Bi≈øhops ≈øhould herein be ≈øoe impious as to advance in ≈øuch a manner, their owne Authority, and ordinances aboue the Apo≈øtles. Yet what is that to proue that the Pree≈øthoode and Deaconry of the Mini≈øters of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies, (who many of them in theis pointes are meere patients, and e≈øteeme of theis things as burdens) cannot ≈øtand with the offices of Apo≈øtles, &c. doth M. Iohn≈øon think that none of our Mini≈øters in England would ≈øuffer the Apo≈øtles to preach in their Cures, without wearing a Surplice, If they might haue their owne wils, or ≈øhould this any whit derogate from their Mini≈øtery, that the
Bi≈øhops therin would not ≈øuffer them to haue their will.

5. It is be≈øids the pre≈øent que≈øtion, and a needle≈ø≈øe thing to ≈øpend time in ju≈øtifying the Canons herein: If the Bi≈øhops therin haue gonne too far, it may ≈øeeme to bee the fault of the Par≈øons, rather then of the Prelacie it ≈øelfe, and therfore to make and vrge ≈øuch Canons, and Traditions as are a fore ≈øaide doth not proue, but that for all that, the Prelacie & in of it ≈øelfe, might ≈øtand well enough with the offices of the Apo≈øtles &c. for tho≈øe offices may of them≈øelues, (If their bee noe other impediment) ≈øtand well one with an other, which in the actions therof doe not (but by accident only) one overthrowe or oppugne the other.

item.hi: The offices of true Pa≈øtors,

and Teachers are by the ordinaunce of Chri≈øt ≈øet in the Church, and imployd in the Mini≈øtery of the word, Sacraments & Church Gouerment, ≈øoe as they may not, with their Eccle≈øia≈øticall functions receaue Cyvill offices, and callings, nor take vpon them princely Titles and dignities. Eph. 4.11, 1. Pet. 5.1. Rom. 12.2.4. Luk. 12.14. and 22.25. 1. Cor. 12.5.8. 1. Tim. 4.13.15.16. 2. Tim. 2.4.

But the officies of Prelates, Prie≈øts, and Deacons of the Church of England, are not ≈øoe, but by their owne Con≈øtitution we ≈øet in the Church, and imployd in the Mini≈øtery ≈øoe as they may al≈øo receaue Cyvill offices and Callings, as to be Iu≈øtices of Peace, &c.
Therfore they are not true Pa≈øtors and Teachers.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: Ther are 4. Termes in this Syllogi≈øme, The gro≈ø≈øe Sophi≈øterye wherof may appeare by the Explanation therof in others wordes.

list.item: True Pa≈øtors & Teachers may not (viz. by Gods lawe) take vpon them Cyvill offices.
The Mini≈øters of England may (viz. by Mans lawe) take vpon them Cyvill offices.
Therfore they are not true Pa≈øtors and Teachers.

div.p: This is the effect of his Argument, & who is ≈øo blind, but hee may ≈øee the fallacie therof. And it is as though we ≈øhould rea≈øon in the like manner again≈øt their owne Mini≈øtery, thus,

list.item: True Pa≈øtors & Teachers may not bee Drunckards, Anabapti≈øts, Famili≈øts.
The Mini≈øters of the Seperation at Am≈øterdam may be Drunckards, Anabapti≈øts, Famili≈øts.
Therfore they are not true Pa≈øtors and Teachers.

div.p: This A≈ø≈øumption is as true as the former, for the ≈øame kinde of Authoritie that permits our Mini≈øters to bee Cyvill Magi≈øtrats, doth permit them to bee Drunckards &c. The goverment vnder which they liue, permitteth the one to more, then our ≈øtate doeth the other.
But I an≈øwer more particulerly.

1. That by the ≈øame lawe, that our Mini≈øters may take vpon them Cyvill Magi≈øtracie; Any true Pa≈øtors, and Teachers, may take vpon them, the ≈øame Authority, and by the ≈øame lawe that true Pa≈øtors and Teachers, may not take Cyvill Authoritye vpon them our Mini≈øters may not take the ≈øame vpon them.

2. All our Mini≈øters may not (noe by the lawes of our State) take vpon them Cyvill Authority; But ≈øuch only as are called ≈øpecially therto, by the fauours, & grace of the Cyvill Magi≈øtrate, not as they are Prelats, Prie≈øts or Deacons, or by vertue of tho≈øe functions; but in re≈øpect of other qualifications. Nether are the forced by any law to adjoyne any ≈øuch Authoritie to their Mini≈øtery, but permitted only. But what if by the lawes of men, Mini≈øters might be Murtherers, Adulterers, Theeus, &c. ≈øhould theis lawes chaunge the nature of their Mini≈øtery? what? of their Mini≈øtery that denye vnto them≈øelues that lycence; would it not rather the more ju≈øtify their Mini≈øtery; when in Con≈øcience of Gods law, they ≈øhall for beare that which fle≈øh, and blood and humaine laws would permit vnto them.

3. Suppo≈øe not onely that it is vnlawfull for any true Pa≈øtors, and Teachers, to bee Cyvill Magi≈øtrats, but that al≈øo by our lawes, all our Mini≈øters, were forced therunto, and that by vertue of their Mini≈øtery, will it thence follow, that for this cau≈øe, they are not true Pa≈øtors and Teachers; May not true Pa≈øtors and Teachers, in their weackne≈ø≈øe, ignorance, and infirmities (the laws of the State requiring the ≈øame) admitt of ≈øome kind of office or Authoritie, for bidden them; but they mu≈øt needs ther vpon cea≈øe to bee true Pa≈øtors, & Teachers? doth the admitting of every vnlawfull thing chaunge the nature of the Mini≈øtery, and make it either noe Mini≈øtery, or a Mini≈øtery of an other kinde.

item.hi: The Mini≈øtery of Chri≈øtian Pa≈øtors, and Teachers,

≈øtandeth by
the word, and ordinance of Chri≈øt, ≈øo as all Churches vnder Heaven, are bound to receaue, and ≈øubmit thervnto.

But the Prelacie, Pree≈øthood and Deaconry of the Ghurch of England ≈øtaundeth only by the Authoritie and Law of man, ≈øoe as other Churches els wher, nether are nor neede to bee ≈øubjecte thervnto; which euen them≈øelues of all ≈øorts haue acknowledged; for which ≈øee Whitgifts defence in the Preface. The An≈øwer to the Ab≈øtraucte pag. 58. The Admonition to the Parlement; The defence of the Godly Mini≈øters the demon≈øtration.
Therfore it is not the Mini≈øtery of Chri≈øtian Pa≈øtors and Teachers.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: I deny the A≈ø≈øumption. The Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies of England, whether of Prelates, Prie≈øts or Deacons, or by what other names ≈øoeuer they be called, for the ≈øub≈øtance therof, ≈øtandeth by the word, and ordinance of Chri≈øt, and not onely by the Authority and law of man: And all other true Churches, are and ought to be ≈øubject, to the ≈øame kinde of Mini≈øtery, and to noe other, that ≈øhall in any E≈ø≈øentiall point of Mini≈øtery differ from ours.

If any Perticuler Par≈øons among≈øt vs, haue bene ≈øoe vnadui≈øed to graunt the A≈ø≈øumption, let them an≈øwer for them≈øelues; Hee hath noe more rea≈øon to binde vs to their opinions, then wee to binde him vnto what≈øoeuer his predece≈ø≈øours Browne, Barrowe, and Greenwood haue held before him. Concerning ≈øome of the particulers, Doctor Whitgifts words are theis, The ≈øub≈øtance,
and nature of Gouerment mu≈øt indeed by taken out of the word of God, and con≈øi≈øteth in theis parts. That the word be truely taught, the Sacraments rightly admini≈øtred, virtue furthered, vice repre≈øsed, and the Church kept in quietne≈ø≈øe and order: The offices of the Church, wherby this Gouerment is wrought bee not namely, and particulerly expre≈øsed in the Scripture, but in ≈øome points left to the di≈øcretion, and libertie of the Church, to be di≈øpo≈øed according to the State of times, Places, and per≈øons. The Author of the An≈øwer to the Ab≈øtract in the place aledged ≈øaith, That it cannot be proued that any ≈øet and exacte particuler forme of di≈øcipline is recomended vnto vs in the word of God. Now are either of theis to affirme, That the Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈øsemblies ≈øtaundeth only by the lawes and Authoritie of Man? Hath M. Iohn≈øon any ≈øhame left in his face that thus ≈øhamefully abu≈øeth the names of learned, and reuerent men, ≈øoe directly contrary to their words and meaning. Is ther not cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect that the other Authors, are in like manner abu≈øed, and that for the better hideing of his fraude, hee forbeareth to quote any particuler places; Being therfore convinced of depravation, in the places particularly quoted, wee may pre≈øume, that if the other places had bene more pertinent, hee would haue giuen vs ≈øome particuler directions al≈øo for the finding of them; And the rather, for that hee cannot be ignorant, that tho≈øe whom ≈øpecially hee fighteth again≈øt in theis ArgumeÃÑts, doe rely vpon the judgement of the Authours following, more then of the former.

item.hi: The offices of Pa≈øtors,

and Teachers, which Chri≈øt hath appointed, are ≈øuch as they which haue them mu≈øt bee members of a true vi≈øible Church, and bound to one perticuler Congregation for the Mini≈øtery and Gouerment therof.

But the Offices of the Prelats, Prie≈øts, and Deacons of the Church of Englande, are ≈øuch as they which haue them, need not bee, neither in their State can bee members of a true vi≈øible Church, but of a fals, neither are bound to one perticuler Congregation for the Mini≈øtery and Gouerment therof, but the Prelates are our whoele Prouinces, and Dioce≈ø≈øes & other inferior Prie≈øts, may haue in that State pluralitie of benefices and Eccle≈øiall Cures &c. which none can deny.
Therfore they are not the Pa≈øtors & Teachers that Chri≈øt hath appointed.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: Though ≈øome parts of the Propo≈øition bee di≈øputable; Yet becau≈øe other be≈øids the Seperation doe hould the whol for truth. I will leaue it in medio.

The A≈ø≈øumption is falce; e≈øpecially if it bee vnder≈øtoode (as it ought to bee) of the offices of ≈øuch Prelats, Prie≈øts, and Deacons as are Mini≈øters of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies. For mo≈øt of tho≈øe which haue ≈øuch offices are, and are bound to be members of true vi≈øible Churches; And cannot in their E≈øtate (they being in all points an≈øwerable to the lawes) be members of a falce Church; They are all (≈øuch excepted as haue ≈øpeciall di≈øpen≈øations) bound to one particuler Congregation, and may not by law, haue more Cures then one; but admitting
of a ≈øeconde, the fir≈øt is voyd; Yea the Prelats theÃÑ≈øelues; though in regard of their Prelaticall office, they are Gouernors of whole Prouinces, & dioce≈ø≈øes, yet it is po≈ø≈øible for them (not with≈øtanding) to be members (in their E≈øtate) of a true vi≈øible Church, and bee bound (as are the Prelats of Scotland) to one particuler congregation for the ≈øpeciall Mini≈øtery and Gouerment therof. And though the other Mini≈øters may haue in that e≈øtate pluralitie of benefices, and Cures, yet it doth not follow, that therfore they are ≈øuch, as in their e≈øtate cannot be members of a true vi≈øible Church; excepte they haue theÃÑ indeede, yea & though they ≈øhould be plurali≈øts indeede, yet (for ought hee hath proued to the contrary) they may bee membres of true vi≈øible Churches, and may each bee bound to one particuler Congregation, for the Mini≈øtery and Gouerment therof.

But what man, except hee were halfe frantick, wold rea≈øon, thus, Our Mini≈øters may bee Plurali≈øts therfore they neither are nor can be true Pa≈øtors and Teachers; Is not this rather one of the honors then blemi≈øhes of our Mini≈øters; That they may be plurali≈øts, and yet are not. If by our lawes their owne A≈ø≈øemblies were e≈øtabli≈øhed If by the ≈øame lawes their Pa≈øtors and Teachers, might bee non re≈øidents or plurali≈øts, or wor≈øe, would they think hem≈øelus euer the wor≈øe for this? would they not rather thinke them≈øelus the better that they are not ≈øoe bad, as by mans lawe they might bee.

item.hi: The Offices Condition and Gouerment of Pa≈øtors and Teachers,
are ≈øuch as noe way impaire the Authority and Supremacy of the Syvill Magi≈øtrate.

But the offices, Condition and Gouerment of Prelates, Prie≈øts & Deacons, are ≈øuch as doe many waies impaire the Authoritie Supremacie and dignity of Kings, and all other Magi≈øtrats both in Civill, and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Cau≈øes. For the Prelates will haue their pre≈øence, voice, and Authority, to be at Parlaments, for enacting of lawes and Statuts for the Common wealth. They are Rulers of whol Prouinces, and dioce≈øses in the Eccle≈øia≈øticall cau≈øes therof.

In Civill State, and dignity, ≈øome of them are aboue all, and all of them, aboue ≈øome of the Nobles, Iu≈øtices, and other Magi≈øtrats of the Lande. Them≈øelues their Courts and officers handle and determine ≈øundry Civill Cau≈øes, and affaires, appertaining to the Magi≈øtracie; They inflict Civill Mults, and puni≈øhments; In their forbidden times they giue licence to Mary. The beneficed Prie≈øts ≈øweare Canonicall obeidience to the Prelats. All the Prie≈øts and Deacons are exempt from the Magi≈øtrats Iuri≈ødiction in diuers things appertaining vnto them, and an≈øwerable onely or cheifly to the Prelats and their officers.
Therfore they are not the onely Pa≈øtors and Teachers ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: The A≈ø≈øumption is falce, nether doe the in≈øtances proue the ≈øame. 1. The Prelats claime their voices in Parlament not as diuine ordinaunces appartaining to their Prelate≈øhip, but as an honor annexed to the ≈øame by the Civill Magi≈øtrate.

2. Their Authority in Cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall ouer Prouinces, &c. is either ≈øuch as the Civill Magi≈øtrate him≈øelfe may execute, and admini≈øter in his owne per≈øon if
hee plea≈øe; or ≈øuch as is not for them, as they are Magi≈øtrats, to execute. The fir≈øt ≈øort they admini≈øter only, by vertue of the Magi≈øtrats owne Commi≈ø≈øion, and therin they cannot impair either his dignity, or Supremacie much le≈ø≈øe in the other part of their Authoritie, which belongeth not to the Magi≈øtrats them≈øelues to execute e≈øpecially when they v≈øe it not nether, without their con≈øent, lycence, and approbation.

3. That all are aboue ≈øome, and ≈øome aboue all of the Nobles, and Iu≈øtices, &c. is a free and voluntary honour graunted vnto them by the Civill Magi≈øtrate, and held in tenure from him, and not claimed (as I thinke) as belonging to their Epi≈øcopall function, by diuine right.

4. Their Courts determine noe other Civill cau≈øes, then the Civill Magi≈øtrate, and his lawes do permit, or if they doe the falt is in the Par≈øons, and not in the Prelat≈øhip; further they inflict Civill puni≈øhments, giue lycences, exacte Oathes, &c. by Authority from the Magi≈øtrat who≈øe ≈øub≈øi≈øtutes therin they are. And therfore the Prelates neither in theis, nor in any of the former in≈øtances can bee ≈øaide to impaire the dignity, Authoritie, or Supremacie of the Civill Magi≈øtrate, when herein they doe all things, in and by the protection of his Authoritie, much le≈ø≈øe can other inferior Mini≈øters who haue noe dealing in the afore≈øaid matters. La≈øtly if all our Mini≈øters be exempt from the Magi≈øtrats Iuri≈ødiction, in ≈øome things appertaining vnto them (but wherin I knowe not) this very exemptioÃÑ it ≈øelfe, is an act of the Magi≈øtrats Iuri≈ødiction & depends, onely vpon his plea≈øure! & how can it theÃÑ, any waies impair the ≈øame. &
hytherto hee hath dealt by Syllogi≈ømes ≈øuch as they are, now for a conclu≈øion of this fir≈øt Argument, hee ≈øhoots at rouers as followeth.

item.hi: To this end diuers other rea≈øons might be aledged, for example If they ≈øay that Arch Bi≈øhops haue the Pa≈øtors, then they haue but two. If Lord Bi≈øhops, then but 26. and what office then haue the Arch Bi≈øhops among≈øt them. If the other Prie≈øtes, then what office haue the Arch Bi≈øhops: and Bi≈øhops ≈øeing God hath or dayned noe higher ordinary Eccle≈øia≈øticall office, as ≈øome of them-≈øelus acknowledg. If they ≈øay the deacons haue the Pa≈øtors office, the ≈øame ab≈øurdity followeth as in the former be≈øids that the works of the deacons office are oppo≈øed to the worke of the Mini≈øtery. Act. 6.2. with. Eph. 4.11. Rom. 12.8. If they ≈øhould ≈øay they haue the Teachers office, it would be known, which of their officiers haue it among≈øt them, and to whom they are adioyned for the worke of Mini≈øtery, as Teachers are to Pa≈øtors, and what office the re≈øt haue whom the accompt not to haue the Teachers office & whether the Teacher ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11. mu≈øt fir≈øt bee deacons; and then Prie≈øtes and permit obeydeince to the Prelates; and that al≈øo is to their ordinaires, and be ≈øylenced and depo≈øed at thtir plea≈øure.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
Here hee thinkes hee hath knitt ≈øuch Gardian knotts as cannot be vntide, without a ≈øword or a bill; but the Simplicitie of the man here in is to bee laughed at, for 1. though ≈øome ≈øhould ≈øay, that either our Arch Bi≈øhops: or Bi≈øhops haue the Pa≈øtors office, yet ther in they doe not exclude the other Mini≈øters, from that which is the ≈øub≈øtance,
and effect of that office, though they ≈øhould from the name; No nor froÃÑ the name neither, but ≈øhould therin onely make degres of pa≈øtours, viz. of Arch Bi≈øhops. over Bi≈øhops and their Dioce≈ø≈øes of Bi≈øhops over Mini≈øters and their Churches, and of Mini≈øters ouer their owne Congregations; Leaving vnto them (not with ≈øtaÃÑding the Superioritie of the other Pa≈øtors) that maine and Sub≈øtantial office of the Pa≈øtor which is enough to define and denominate a Pa≈øtor. And therfore they may make ≈øuch Pa≈øtors, as are over whole Prouinces but two, & ≈øuch as are over whole dioce≈ø≈øes but, 26. and yet hold al≈øo without any ab≈øurditie, that their are al≈øo as many Pa≈øtors be≈øyds, as ther are Mini≈øters of a particuler Congregation. And though it ≈øhould be graunted that herein they were deceaued in making Provinciall and dioce≈øme Pa≈øtors; yet the ≈øorteing of vnproper Pa≈øtors; with true or the ≈øubiecting of true Pa≈øtors vnto other ≈øorts of Pa≈øtors, doth not nece≈ø≈øarily make the true Pa≈øtors fals, ≈øoe long as vnder them they performe, the name, and ≈øub≈øtantiall duties of true Pa≈øtors; which all the Mini≈øters of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies doe, or by the lawes ought to doe.

2. If any hould that the Mini≈øters of perticular Congregations, onely are Pa≈øtors, theÃÑ they may without any ab≈øurdity hould that they Arch Bi≈øhops, and Bi≈øhops, are generall CoÃÑmi≈ø≈øioners vnder the King to ≈øee that the Pa≈øtors doe their duties, and in that regard, may al≈øo Metaphorically, and in another ≈øence bee called Pa≈øtors, as Princes them≈øelves are ≈øoe called, in good and approued Authors; and what ab≈øurdity can follow vpon this? Or what if they which hould the Mini≈øters of perticular
Congregations to bee Pa≈øtors, could not tell what to make of the office of Arch Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, whats that to the purpo≈øe? are not our Mini≈øters, and Teachers therfore Pa≈øtors, becau≈øe they which ≈øhall hould them to bee ≈øoe, cannot tell what to make of the Calling of Arch Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops?

3. Though this ≈øhould bee yelded vnto him that all Pa≈øtors are equall, and that the Pa≈øtors of perticular Congregations, are the highe≈øt ordinary Eccle≈øia≈øticall officers; yet ≈øhould this make nothing to the confirming of his conceit, That our Mini≈øters are not therfore true Pa≈øtors and Teachers, becau≈øe then Arch Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops ≈øhould be excluded; for this doth not exclude them from being Commi≈ø≈øioners, and Vi≈øitors in cau≈øes eccle≈øia≈øticall vnder the King over the Pa≈øtors, and Churches, of ≈øuch and ≈øuch Prouinces and Dioce≈ø≈øes, which is to giue theÃÑ their principall honour, & due. 4. Concerning the Teachers office (not to contende needle≈øly, with him about the nature and quality therof but to ≈øuppo≈øe a Teacher in that ≈øence which hee meaneth) This may rea≈øonably bee held; That ≈øome of our Mini≈øters, (whether Prie≈øts or Deacons ≈øo called, or whether Par≈øons, Vicars, Curats or Stipendaries) are Pa≈øtors and ≈øome Teachers, That ≈øo many of them as haue and v≈øe the gift, not onely of doctrine and in≈øtruction, but of Exhortation, are Pa≈øtors, That tho≈øe which wanting the power of Exhortation, and yet haue & v≈øe the gift of in≈øtruction and doctrine are ≈øuch Teachers, as hee meaneth. And therfore herein al≈øo if it ≈øhould bee yealded vnto him, That it were fit that every Congregation ≈øhould haue both theis offices; and that the Teacher
≈øhould be the Pa≈øtors A≈ø≈øi≈øtant, yet it doth not follow, but that in want of ≈øufficient men, for both theis offices in every Congregation, ≈øome may inioy one, and ≈øome an other. For if the Churches of their owne way, and con≈øtitution, may bee without both Pa≈øtors & Teachers, and that for a long time, till men may be cho≈øen vnto that office? Why may not a Church much more in the like nece≈ø≈øity retaine a Pa≈øtor without a Teacher, or a Teacher without a Pa≈øtor, Can hee proue by any colour out of Gods word, That one cannot bee called vnto, or execute the office of a Pa≈øtor vntill hee haue a Teacher to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him, or that hee cannot execute the office of a Doctor, except hee do it as an actuall a≈ø≈øi≈øtant of ≈øome Pa≈øtor? If not, then is this a mo≈øt frivolous demaunde, when hee askes to whome our Teachers are adioynd for the worke of their Mini≈øtery: nether doe the places hee quoteth viz. Eph. 4.11. RoÃÑ. 12.7. proue any ≈øuch matter. 5. As idle and impertinent is that demande which followeth whether the Teachers ≈øpoken of Eph. 4.11. mu≈øt fir≈øt bee Deacons, & then Prie≈øts, & promi≈øe obeidience to Prelats, & be ≈øilenced and depo≈øed at their plea≈øures. For what if noe ≈øuch matters bee required of Teachers by Paul, either in that or any other place, doth it thervpon follow, that their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to ≈øuch things, makes them noe Teachers! may not Magi≈øtrats, & others al≈øo require, ≈øome things of Teachers, not required by the Apo≈øtles, but they mu≈øt needs thervpon, become no Teachers? But what repugnauncie is their in theis matters, to the office of a Teacher? To be a Deacon in the intent of our lawes what is it, but (as him≈øelfe out of our booke of ordination hath in effect publi≈øhed it) To read the Seriptures, Pag. 31. & to pray in the Church to Catechi≈øe the IoÃÑger ≈øort, to baptize & to preach
if the Bi≈øhop ≈øhal think him ≈øitt. what is it to bee a Prie≈øt, or Presbyter in our law? hath not him≈øelf al≈øo taught vs? viz. Pag. 32. To haue authoritie to Preach the word, and to Mini≈øter the holy Sacramentes in the Congregation, wher hee ≈øhalbe appointed, what obeidience doe they (promi≈øe to Prelates in the intent of the lawe? but onely in things that they ≈øhal judge hone≈øt, and lawfull, and not repugnaunt to the word of God; what is it to bee ≈øylenced and depo≈øed, but to forbear to Mini≈øter publiquly (as them≈øelues doe al≈øo forbeare) vpon the Magi≈øtrats plea≈øure: for the Bi≈øhops plea≈øure ≈øoe far as they proceede according to the lawes, is the Magi≈øtrats plea≈øure, otherwi≈øe it is but a per≈øonall fault. And wherein Imarvaile doe any of the≈øe acts, ≈øo oppugne the office of a Teacher, that they cannot ≈øtand together! wher doth Paul forbid any of theis acts vnto the Teacher? or if hee ≈øhould, doth euery Act forbidden to a Teacher, make him noe Teahcer?

q.hi: Wheras ≈øome alledge that the people were to hear the Scribs and Phare≈øees ≈øitting in Mo≈øes Chayre it is to bee noted, that they were Leuits and Prie≈øts and therfore had the true offices appointed by Mo≈øes. This therfore is nothing for a fals Mini≈øtery, ≈øuch as theirs is proued to bee. further to bee a Pharefye was not to haue a new kinde of Mini≈øtery, but to bee of a ≈øpeciall Sect among≈øt the Iewes that pretended more ≈øtrict ob≈øervances of the law, and might bee of any Tribe. La≈øtly though the were corrupt, yet did the hould, that very true Mini≈øter mu≈øt bee from heauen: and this haue the forward Preachers acknowledged, as T. C. pag. 83.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
Here ab≈øurdly, and Childi≈øhly hee goeth about to an≈øwer ≈øuch an objection, as noe body ever made again≈øt any thing contained in the former Argument. This Argument onely is v≈øed in generall to ≈øhewe, that ≈øome corruptions in Mini≈øters and Churches are not of that nature, that men ≈øhould therfore ≈øeperate from all Spirituall Communion with them, And wher hee ≈øaith, that this is nothing for any fals Mini≈øtery neuer ordained of the Lord, ≈øuch as ours is proued to bee: Noe man ever brought it to proue any ≈øuch matter; But onely to proue that ≈øuch corruptions as are in our Mini≈øtery, ought noe more to hinder, communion with our Mini≈øters, then the corruptions in the Mini≈øtery of the Scribes and Phare≈øees, did hinder the communion, with their Mini≈øtery, and that the corruptions in our Mini≈øtery doe noe more argue our Mini≈øters to bee fals Mini≈øters, then their corruptions, did argue them to bee fals Mini≈øters: Nether hath hee brought any Argument to proue our Mini≈øters fals Mini≈øters, but either ≈øuch corruptions, as the Scribes and Phare≈øees were guilty of, in as high if not a higher degree, or in re≈øpect of their names, in that they are called Prie≈øts and Deacons; So that if the Scribes & Phare≈øees were true Mini≈øters, not with ≈øtanding their names, and other corruptions, our Mini≈øters cannot bee fals, in regard of the like names and corruptions: furthermore if to be expounders of the Law, bee ≈øufficient to argue their Mini≈øtery to bee a true Mini≈øtery, nothwith≈øtanding their names of Scribes and Phare≈øees, with other vile & gro≈ø≈øe corruptions; why may not the Preaching of the
word, and admini≈øtration of the Sacraments bee ≈øufficient to argue, our Mini≈øters to bee true Pa≈øtors, and Teachers, notwith≈øtaÃÑding that in the mouth of the law, they are ≈øometimes called Prie≈øts and Deacons. For otherwi≈øe in the mouths of men; euen of the Bi≈øhops them≈øelues they are not ≈øo called; except ≈øometimes by Metaphoricall allu≈øions to the Leviticall Pree≈øthood; But they are v≈øually ≈øo called onely by profane Athei≈øts, or ignorant people, with whom in this point, the Seperation goeth hand in hand.

2. To bee a Phare≈øie was not onely (as hee minceth the matter) to be of a ≈øpeciall Sect among≈øt the Iewes, that pretended more ≈øtrict ob≈øeruances of the law then others. But al≈øo (which as it is to be feared with a fraudulent minde hee concealeth) to joine mainy humaine Traditions, and will-wor≈øhips to the wor≈øhip and ≈øeruice of God (wherby they are ≈øaide by Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, in vaine to wor≈øhip God, and to make the commaundements of God of none effect;) making more accompt of; and vrging with more ≈øeverity the ≈øaid Traditions, then Gods owne laws; And in like manner, wee affirme, That to bee a Prie≈øt and Deacon, in the intent of our law (what≈øoeuer the words may ring to the contrary in ≈øome mens eares) is (at the wor≈øt) to bee ≈øuch a kinde of pa≈øtor and Teacher, as is content, over and be≈øids tho≈øe duties of the Mini≈øtery which Chri≈øt requires of them to yeald conformity al≈øo to humaine Traditions, of noe wor≈øe nature and quality in them≈øelues, then tho≈øe which the Phare≈øies v≈øed in or about Gods ≈øeruice, wherin to ≈øuppo≈øe that they ≈øin, yet cannot this their ≈øin be ≈øo repugnant to the Mini≈øtery of Chri≈øt as that of the Scribes and Phare≈øies,
which they are forced to acknowledge to be a true Mini≈øtery, In that they were the vrgers of Traditions, wheras our Mini≈øters (for the mo≈øt part) onely yeald vnto them, either in obeidience and loue; or feare of the Magi≈øtrat that commaundes them. La≈øtly wheras hee argues them true Mini≈øters by this, that though they were very corrupt, yet the did ≈øtill hould that euery Mini≈øtery mu≈øt bee from Heaven, and not of men. It de≈øerues rather to bee laughed at, then an≈øwered. For may not yea doe the fal≈øe≈øt Mini≈øtery that are or ever haue bene, hould ≈øo much, at lea≈øt in ≈øuch a ≈øence and meaning as the Phare≈øies might hould it. And can hee name any among≈øt vs, that houlds not as much?

item.hi: NOne may heare or haue any Spiritually communion with the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
Such is the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande.

p.hi: None may heare haue any Spirituall communion with the ≈øame.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: I graunt the Propo≈øition; taking the words in the plaine and common ≈øence viz. vnder≈øtanding by the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øtacie. The admini≈øtration and di≈øpen≈øation of the things of Antichri≈øt; otherwi≈øe to communicate ≈øpiritually with any Mini≈øters what ≈øoeuer onely in the holy things of Chri≈øt, is not to communicate with the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øtacy, no though the Mini≈øters be Mini≈øters therof. Nether do the 5. Rea≈øons following whereby hee needle≈øly proues his prepo≈øition, proue it vnlawfull to heare or haue any ≈øpirituall communion with the Mini≈øters of Antichri≈øt, then, when they Mini≈øter the things of Chri≈øt.
For the profe of the A≈ø≈øumption hee makes a terrible mu≈øter if no le≈ø≈øe then 7. Arguments. But let vs pull vp our Spirets, and ≈øee what is in them, one by one.

item.hi: The Mini≈øtery of Deacons and Prie≈øts ordained by the Prelats thervnto is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy.
The Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande, is ≈øuch a Mini≈øtery.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
Hee brought this very Argument to proue the fir≈øt Rea≈øon and now hee brings it againe for a profe of his ≈øecond Rea≈øon: And is not this a learned kind of rea≈øoning? when hee will make a ≈øhew of multitudes of
Rea≈øons again≈øt vs, and yet all of them come to one i≈ø≈øue and lie vpon one ground, and depend vpon one profe; ≈øo that the overthrowe of one, is the overthrowe of all: But his childi≈øh vanitie herein wee ≈øhall better perceaue in that which followeth.

Both the Propo≈øition and A≈ø≈øumption are fals; For 1. It is not nece≈ø≈øary, that the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts, and Deacons, though ordained by Antichri≈øt him≈øelfe, ≈øhould be the Mini≈øtery of his Apo≈øtacy; But not with≈øtanding his ordination, their Mini≈øtery may be the Mini≈øtery of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt; As was the Mini≈øtery of Luther, Hu≈ø≈øe, Wickliffe and others.

2. The Mini≈øtery of ≈øuch manner of Prie≈øts and Deacons, as the Prelats ordaine, (or by the lawes ought to ordaine) is the true Mini≈øtery of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and for the ≈øub≈øtance therof, directly contrary to the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy.
3. The Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies, is not (as I haue ≈øhewed before) the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts and Deacons properly ≈øo taken, but of Pa≈øtors and Teachers.
The Propo≈øition hee proueth as followeth by two Arguments.

item.hi: The Mini≈øtery of Deacons and Prie≈øts which accompts it ≈øelfe to bee Chri≈øts, and yet was not ≈øet by Chri≈øt in his Church, for the worke of his Mini≈øtery, is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy.
Such is the Mini≈øtery of Deacons and Prie≈øts, ordained by the Prelats therevnto.

p.hi: It is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: This Argument is it which hee bringeth for the fir≈øt Rea≈øon of all; and here hee brings it to proue that which before was brought to proue it. For hee proues, That our Mini≈øtery is not ≈øet by Chri≈øt in his Church, by this becau≈øe it is the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts and Deacons, and ≈øo by con≈øequent of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie. Here hee proues, That the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts and Deacons is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie, Becau≈øe it is a Mini≈øtery, that was not ≈øet by Chri≈øt in his Church; This doth hee mo≈øt gro≈øly runne round in a circle, as if I ≈øhould proue that his Mini≈øtery is vnlawfull, becau≈øe hee is a Schi≈ømatick, and that hee is a Schi≈ømatick, becau≈øe his Mini≈øtery is vnlawful. The 2. Rea≈øon wherby he proues his Propo≈øition followeth.

item.hi: 2. If the Prelates of the Church of England haue ≈øuch offices, and Gouerment as be ≈øpeciall parts of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie, then the Mini≈øtery ordained by them thervnto mu≈øt needs bee the Mini≈øtery of that Apo≈øta≈øie.
But the Prelats of the Church of England haue ≈øuch offices and gouerment, as bee ≈øpeciall parts of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy.
Therfore the Mini≈øtery ordained by them is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
The con≈øequent is manife≈øt, becau≈øe the fruit mu≈øt needs bee as the tree is. Mat. 7.16. and who can bring a clean thing out of filthine≈øse. Iob 14.4.
The A≈øsumption is proued.

1. Who≈øoever (be≈øids Chri≈øt) haue ≈øuch offices and Gouerment, wherby the claime to bee ≈øpirituall Lords, the haue the offices,
and Gouerment which are ≈øpeciall parts of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy, and are indeed very Antichri≈øts them≈øelues.
But ≈øuch are the Prelats of the Church of Englande.
Therfore the haue ≈øuch offices and Gouerments, as are ≈øpeciall purts of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy.
The Propo≈øition is proued by tho≈øe places of Scripture which teach that there is but one ≈øpirituall Lord, the Lord Ie≈øus.

The A≈øsumption is proued by the lawes, and Statutes of the land, wherin they are called Lords Spirituall, and in their Canons they take vpon them to pre≈øcribe their owne ordinaunces to the Ghurch for the wor≈øhip of God, and binde the ≈øpiret and cou≈øcience to the acknowledgement, and approbation therof, and to giue the holy Gho≈øt.

2. The offices and Gouerment of ≈øuch Bi≈øhops, as are ouer Dioce≈øan, and Prouinciall Churches, and exerci≈øe Eccle≈øia≈øticall juri≈ødiction ouer all the Mini≈øters and people therin, are ≈øpeciall parts of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
But ≈øuch are the Prelates of the Church of Englande.

p.hi: They haue ≈øuch offices and gouerment as bee ≈øpecially parts of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
1. I deny the coÃÑ≈øequent of the Propo≈øition of the 1. Sillogi≈øme. The officers & gouernors of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy, may & haue ordained ≈øome things that are Chri≈øtian, Nether doth the ≈øaying of Chri≈øt or Iob proue the con≈øequent; for though it ≈øhould be graunted vnto him, that the gouernors of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy haue ordained this Mini≈øtery; yet doth it not follow that it is therfore a propre & meere fruit of Antichri≈øt, but may be an
dentall effect, as are many other things which hee ordaineth agreable to Chri≈øts owne ordinaunces, ≈øo that hee mu≈øt proue that our Mini≈øtery ordained by the Pope or Bi≈øhops, doth as properly flowe from the nature of their office and gouerment, as figs from a fig tree, or grapes from a vine, or filthy water from a foule fountaine; The contrary wherof is in this ca≈øe mo≈øt euident. For leaue the bare names and tytles, and con≈øider our Mini≈øtery in all the e≈ø≈øentiall parts, and offices therof, and it is a po≈ø≈øible, either for a Presbythery, or for any perticuler Church, ≈øuch in con≈øtitution as their owne, to ordaine the like Mini≈øtery in all points and re≈øpects, with all the defects and faults therof.

2. Concerning the fir≈øt profe of the A≈ø≈øumption, The Propo≈øition may bee denied; It being one thing to bee, and another to make claine to bee, for euery one is not that which hee claimeth to bee, The In≈øtances alledged to proue the A≈ø≈øumption, either are fals or proue it not. The lawes may giue their titles, to men which they doe not claime. Neither doe either their Canons or practis ≈øhew that they pre≈øcribe their owne ordinances for wor≈øhip or propound to binde mens con≈øciences to the acknowledgement of any ≈øuch matter. The profe≈ø≈øe the contrary, and vrge their owne ordinaunces onely vnder the name of things indifferent, Though therfore in error of iudgement, they may, and happily doe commande ≈øuch ordinances of their owne, as are diuine wor≈øhip, and in ≈øuch a manner as it bindeth con≈øcience (which M. Iohn≈øons owne Church in many ca≈øes may doe, except they think them≈øelues priviledged from error) yet they prote≈øting again≈øt any ≈øuch power and authority, they cannot be
≈øaide therin to arrogate the office of Spirituall Lords, in that ≈øence at lea≈øt, in which Chri≈øt is ≈øaid to bee the only Spirituall Lord. And though in their ordination of Mini≈øters, they v≈øe as a ceremoniall ≈øpeech to ≈øay, Receaue the holy Gho≈øt; and therin peraduenture offer ≈øome force vnto the Scripture vnto which the allude; yet they di≈øclaime al actuall power and authority of giuing the per≈øon or gifts of the holy Gho≈øt vnto men.

It ≈øhall bee needle≈ø≈øe in this controver≈øie, to ≈øpend time in the defence of the calling of Bi≈øhops any further then the nece≈ø≈øity of the argument requires, Onely for the further clearing of the truth in the differences of them of the Seperation not only from the Bi≈øhops, but from the other ≈øort of Mini≈øters al≈øo, which doe not approue of their callings, I offer theis pointes vnto them to con≈øider of advi≈øedly.
1. Whether the Supreame Magi≈øtrate haue not power to ouer ≈øee, and Gouerne all the ≈øeverall Churches with in his dominions, yea whether hee bee not bound ≈øo to doe?
2. Whether for his further helpe and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance herein hee may not make choi≈øe of graue learned and reuerent men to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him in the ≈øame gouerment.

3. Whether by vertue of his power theis per≈øons thus called to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Supreame Magi≈øtrate, may not lawfully try the gifts of all the ≈øeverall Mini≈øters with in his dominions, and giue publique approbation of the worthy, & inhibit tho≈øe which they finde vnworthy, froÃÑ the execution of their Mini≈øtery, & whether they may not vi≈øit the ≈øeverall Mini≈øters and Churches, conuent them before them, examine them, how they haue behaued
them≈øelues in their places, and puni≈øh the blame worthy.

4. Whether for the more ea≈øy and orderly Gouerment of the ≈øaid Churches, ≈øo far forth as appertaineth to him, hee may not devide his kingdom (as ours is) into Provinces a≈ø≈øigning over each of them vnder him≈øelf ≈øome ≈øpeciall Magi≈øtrat for learning and experience to over≈øee, and gouerne all the perticuler Churches there, and whether hee may not ≈øubdevide tho≈øe Provinces into Dioce≈ø≈øes, a≈ø≈øigning al≈øo to them, other more inferior officers, vnder him, and his provinciall officers, to over ≈øee the ≈øeverall Churches with in ≈øuch, and ≈øuch a precincte?

5. Whether it doe de≈øtroy the nature of a Mini≈øteriall or a perticular true vi≈øible Church, that many of them ≈øhould appertaine vnto one Provinciall or Dioce≈øame gouerment, though in that re≈øpect they ≈øhould bee held and reputed, but for one Provinciall, or Dioce≈øame Church?

6. Whether Antichri≈øt hauing v≈øurped the Kings Supremacy, and taken into his hands this authority and corrupted the ≈øame, hath made it now vnlawfull for the Magi≈øtrate to execute the ≈øame in manner and forme a fore ≈øaide; or whether the Iuri≈ødiction a fore ≈øaide doe not directly and properly belonge to the Civill Magi≈øtrate, and not to Antichri≈øt. But by v≈øurpation; And whether his v≈øurpation of this office can make it a part of his Apo≈øta≈øie in tho≈øe places where it is re≈øtored againe to the Supreame Magi≈øtrate.

7. Whether the Supreame Magi≈øtrate recerving this his right from Antichri≈øt, and together with it happily
taking al≈øo to him≈øelfe ≈øome thing al≈øo that belonges to the Kingdom of Antichri≈øt: & executing the ≈øame either in his owne per≈øon or by others, together with his owne lawfull right, whether (I ≈øay) this doe de≈øtroy his owne lawfull right? and whether the ≈øubiect is ever the le≈ø≈øe bounde to ≈øubject them≈øelues vnto the ≈øame right, either in his owne per≈øon, or his ≈øub≈øtitute.

Hither to hee hath indevoured to proue the Propo≈øition of the fir≈øt Argument, wherby hee would confirme, the A≈ø≈øumption of his 2. rea≈øon, and now hee ≈øets vpon the profe of the A≈ø≈øumption. Namely, That the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande, is the Mini≈øtery of Deacons, and Prie≈øts ordained by the Prelats ther vnto. This hee ≈øaith is proued by the Canons con≈øtitutions & ob≈øeruation of our Church; And this hee confirmeth fir≈øt by a longe, tedious and idle reher≈øall of the forme of ordination of our Mini≈øters, be≈øtowing co≈øt to print, in a manner our whole booke of ordination.
2. By certaine of the late Canons pre≈ø≈øing ≈øub≈øcription, conformity, and an acknowledgement of the lawfulnes of the calling of Bi≈øhops, and of their ordination.

3. By certaine ≈øharpe ≈øpeeches of ≈øome Martyrs and of ≈øome others of our owne Nation again≈øt the Arch-Bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhohs, & other of the cleargy of their times. In the relation of which pointes hee ≈øpends ≈øome 5 leaves; wherin ≈øtill hee runs in a circle begging one of his arguments to proue an other, So that one of his Arguments are as good as all, and all no better then one; This may ≈øuffice for an≈øwere. 1. That if all particulars mentioned in the booke of ordination ≈øhould bee ≈øtrictly, and preci≈øely practized (as alwayes they are
not) yet ther is not one clau≈øe in the whole forme of ordination by him cited, that doth nece≈ø≈øarily argue them, which are ≈øo ordained, to bee true and proper Prie≈øts, and Deacons; But if ther were and if al≈øo the Mini≈øters ordained, were anointed with oile, if their crownes were ≈øhawen, and they had power giuen to offer the abhominable Idole of the Ma≈ø≈øe, yet this is not ≈øufficient to argue, that their Mini≈øtery is the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts, &c. except in their Mini≈øtery they ≈øhould execute the ≈øame. If their owne Church ≈øhould ordaine one to the Mini≈øtery of a Pa≈øtor, and ≈øhould in their ordination require him only to preach the worde ≈øincerely, and to admini≈øter the Sacraments according to Chri≈øts in≈øtitution, and yet in his practis and execution, hee ≈øhould do nothing, but ≈øing Ma≈ø≈øe and Mattens, and they ≈øhould accept of this Mini≈øtery, and no other, at his hands; would any that is in his wits, ≈øay that this mans Mini≈øtery, is the Mini≈øtery of a Pa≈øtor: becau≈øe hee was in formality of words & ceremonies ordained to that office, how much le≈ø≈øe can any ≈øay that our Mini≈øtery is the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts, when they doe not only execute any ≈øuch office, but the clean contrary; and when in their ordination not ≈øo much as any parte of a Prie≈øts office (properly ≈øo taken) is a≈ø≈øigned vnto them, but only the name; and not ≈øo much as their name in their orders written in Latin, which are to interpret the meaning of the Engli≈øh worde.

2. Though the Mini≈øters ≈øhould doe all things required, by the canons, and ≈øhould bee every way an≈øwerable vnto them, And though the Te≈øtimonies of our Martyrs and others were yealded to bee true, yet mu≈øt
hee ≈øtreiue hard, that can from either or both, argue that our Mini≈øters, are indeede Prie≈øts, except in a Metaphoricall, and borrowed ≈øpeech.
The other Arguments wherby hee proueth the maine A≈ø≈øumption of the 2. Rea≈øon viz. That the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of England, is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy, followe.

item.hi: The Mini≈øtery of the Prelacie profe≈øsing it ≈øelfe to bee Chri≈øts,

and yet ≈øtanding in ≈øuch an e≈øtate as it doth not obey Ie≈øus Chri≈øt in his ordinance of Mini≈øtery, wor≈øhip and gouerment of the Church, as their Prophet, Prie≈øt and King, is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy.
Such is the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande.

p.hi: It is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
To the Propo≈øition I an≈øwer, That not onely the Mini≈øtery of the Prelates, but of a Presbytery, or any Church what≈øoever that ≈øtands in ≈øuch an e≈øtate, is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øtacie; And not onely the Mini≈øtery of the Prelats, but any other Mini≈øtery els vpon earth, may ≈øtand in ≈øuch an e≈øtate, as that it may in diuers, and ≈øundry Perticulers of (ignorance or infirmity) di≈øobey Chri≈øt in his owne ordinances of Mini≈øtery, wor≈øhip, and gouerment of the Church, and in that re≈øpect, and ≈øo far forth bee the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy, & yet bee al≈øo the Mini≈øtery of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Hee proues
the Propo≈øition by 19. places of Scripture; to as much purpo≈øe, as if by as many Te≈øtimonies, hee ≈øhould proue that it is day lighte at high noone; Except hee meane, That that is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie, doth not in euery perticuler obey Chri≈øt in his owne ordinances of Mini≈øtery. But which his 19. proofes haue no more force to proue it, then to proue that their is a man in the moone, as any may ≈øee that hath nothing els to doe, but to examine them.

2. I deny the A≈ø≈øumption; The Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies, though it bee ordained by the Prelats, and bee ≈øubject vnto them, yet it is not their Mini≈øtery, but the Mini≈øtery of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt; They preaching his worde, & admini≈øtring his Sacraments; And it doth (if it bee an≈øwerable to the law:) obey Chri≈øt in all the maine e≈ø≈øentiall parts of his owne ordinaunce of Mini≈øtery, &c. And in all other points (for ought hee can proue to the contrary) as far as the Lord hath revailed the truth vnto them which exerci≈øe the ≈øame.

But (≈øaith hee) the A≈øsumption is evident by that which hath bene ≈øaid in the 1. Rea≈øon and their Con≈øtitution it ≈øelfe ≈øhewes it, in that they are ≈øo farre from obeing Chri≈øt in his ordinances of Mini≈øtery &c. as that they execute the Mini≈øtery and gouerment of an other Arch Bi≈øschop, L. Bi≈øhop then Chri≈øt of an Arch-Deacon, Par≈øon, Vicar, &c. as al≈øo in their reading; prayers out of a booke, and ob≈øerving other humaine inventions, and in their Church Gouerment according to Canons, Courts, &c. which were neuer appointed by Chri≈øt. To omit that here againe, hee begs his fir≈øt rea≈øon to proue his ≈øeconde, If the A≈ø≈øumntion haue noe better evidence, the evidence is fals, as I haue made it evident, in the
An≈øwer to the fir≈øt rea≈øon? Nether hath hee there or els where (in any of tho≈øe other of their wrightings which hee ≈øends vs vnto pag. 40.) proued that our Mini≈øters do not obey Chri≈øt, in his ordinance of Mini≈øtery, wor≈øhip, and Gouerment, yea though it ≈øhould be graunted that they execute the Mini≈øtery, and Gouerment of other Arch Bi≈øhops, and L. Bi≈øhops be≈øids Chri≈øt. And though they ≈øhould bee Arch Deacons, Par≈øons, Vicars, reading ≈øtinted prayers, &c. For all this may bee donne yea and they may ≈øinne ≈øome way in doing all this, and yet they may obey Chri≈øt in all the maine e≈ø≈øentiall and ≈øub≈øtantiall pointes of his Mini≈øtery wor≈øhip and Gouerment.

item.hi: The Mini≈øtery of Chri≈øtians which is oppo≈øed again≈øt and exalted aboue the holy things, Mini≈øtery & ordinances of Chri≈øt,
is the Mini≈øtery of Autichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie, 2. The≈ø. 2.3.4. with 1. Ioh. &c.
Such is the Mini≈øtery of their Church A≈øsemblies.
It is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
The A≈øsumption is euident, 1. Aman may peaceably receaue or admini≈øter, their holy things in their manner, by vertue of their Deacoury or Prie≈øthoode, receaued from their Prelats.

But if any doe admini≈øter or receaue the holy things of God by the offices of Pa≈øtors, and Teachers entred into and executed according to the Te≈øtament of Chri≈øt, they are reviled and per≈øecuted.

2. Their Prelacie, Prie≈øthoode, and Deaconry is the very meanes of thru≈øting away and keeping out of the
Church the Mini≈øtery and order which Chri≈øt hath appointed, which ≈øome of them≈øelues hereto fore haue acknowledged, and written.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: 1. The Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies being an≈øwerable to the lawes, is not a Mini≈øtery exalted in any thing, aboue the Mini≈øtery of Chri≈øt, but the very ≈øame in nature and qualitie, though in ≈øome accidents it may differ. In which difference, if ther bee any ≈øinne, it is of ignorance, or infirmitie in the Mini≈øters; which may in as high or a higher degree befall vnto the be≈øt Mini≈øters that ever were ≈øince the Apo≈øtles times.

2. The holy things which they admini≈øter are the holy things of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and not of their owne, & by vertue of that Prie≈øthoode and Deaconry which they haue receaued they may not admini≈øter any other holy things but what Chri≈øt Ie≈øus requireth. The other things which they admini≈øter are iudged by them which admini≈øter them; onely things indifferent and matters of order, wherein if they which v≈øe them be deceaved, it is but ≈øuch an error as worthy Martyrs of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt haue bene ≈øubject vnto, and not ≈øufficient to make their Mini≈øtery an Antichri≈øtian Mini≈øtery.

3. The Prelats doe not per≈øecute any true Pa≈øtors and Teachers, ≈øo much for Mini≈øtering any of the holy things of Chri≈øt, as for refu≈øing to conforme to ≈øome ≈øpeciall ordinances of their owne, which they doe not hould to bee holy things, but matters of order, & which by rea≈øons they haue indevoured to proue to bee ≈øo: wherein the practis of Prelats is noe more extreame,
then their owne, who cen≈øure as farr as they can, in all extremity, all them whoe doe not in al points, conforme and agree to their owne orders, ceremonies and Church policie.

4. It can never bee proued, that the admittance of this Mini≈øtery, is a hindrance of a better, but rather it is a meanes to keepe out a wors, and away in time to bring in a better, if a better bee to be brought in, for by yealding to ≈øome things that may be bettered & is ≈øo wi≈øhed and indeavored, a dore is opened to Mini≈øter many holy things, which otherwi≈øe ≈øhould bee ≈øhut. And if it bee as lawfull, for vs to conjecture, as for him, Their general Schi≈øme and rent from this Mini≈øtery, hath bene one maine and principall meanes to vphoulde it as it is.

item.hi: The Mini≈øtery which is ≈øuch as in the nature and condition therof it pertaineth not to any body or e≈øtate either civill or eccle≈øia≈øticall but only to the body or kingdome of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
Such is the Mini≈øtery of their Church A≈øsemblies.
It is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.

The A≈øsumption is clear, in as much as their Prelacie, Prie≈øthood, and Deaconry; is ≈øuch that the Civill State may bee perfect without, them and the Church of Chri≈øt may bee compleat without them, onely the body, and Kingdome of the Romi≈øh Antichri≈øt, cannot bee full and furni≈øhed in all the offices therof without them.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: For An≈øwere to the A≈ø≈øumption,

1. Concerning the Prelacie (though it bee not any Mini≈øtery of any of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies, and therfore Idly vrged, in this and all the other Arguments) this may bee ≈øaide; 1. That the principall, and mo≈øt honorable parts therof is onely v≈øurped by Antichri≈øt, and doth not appertaine to him, but to the Iuri≈ødiction of the Supreame Magi≈øtrats, and States.

2. That the State of a Chri≈øtian common wealth cannot bee perfect, without ≈øome generall vi≈øitors, and over≈øeers of Churches. 3. That though a perticuler Church or congregation may bee compleat without them, yet for the nece≈ø≈øary vnion, and agreement of the ≈øeverall Churches in Chri≈øtian Provinces, and Kingdoms, it is fit and agreable to rea≈øon, and noe wayes repugnant to Gods word, that vnder the Supreame Magi≈øtrate ther ≈øhould bee, other Governors to protect, and incorrage tho≈øe Mini≈øters, and Churches which doe their dutie, and to puni≈øh tho≈øe which ≈øhall offende. Wherin if either through warrant of humaine lawes, or ≈øome per≈øonall corruption, they ≈øhall in ≈øome things pa≈ø≈øe their bounds, they doe no more then any other officers either Civill or Eccle≈øia≈øticall, through frailtie, & infirmitie may doe. 4. That the kingdome of Antichri≈øt cannot be furni≈øhed, in all the offices therof without the Authority of Civill Magi≈øtrats, and therfore this ≈øeemes to make as much again≈øt the calling of civill Magi≈øtrats as Bi≈øhops.

2. Concerning the Mini≈øtery of our Prie≈øts and Deacons,
≈øuch as it is, or by lawe ought to be in our Church A≈ø≈øemblies, the Church of Chri≈øt cannot bee compleat without it; yea it is noe Church without it. Nether can the kingdome of Antichri≈øt ≈øtand before it, Nether will hee ever proue the contrary.

item.hi: The Mini≈øtery which is ≈øuch as the body of Antichri≈øt the man of ≈øinne,
cannot without it be compleat in all the members and canonicall functions therof is the Mini≈øtery of Autichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
Such is the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande.
It is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
The A≈øsumption is proued by the Canons, Pontificall, and e≈øtate of the Romi≈øh Antichri≈øt.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: This Argument is but the taile of the former, & therfore needs noe further An≈øwer, it being cut of in the an≈øwer to the former. The Canons Pontificall, & State. of the Romi≈øh Antichri≈øt doe manife≈øt the countrary, which haue and doe cur≈øe and per≈øecute with ≈øworde and fier, ≈øuch a Mini≈øtery as is the Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies: if it bee in all points to the intent of the law.

item.hi: The Mini≈øtery of Deacons, Prie≈øts, and Prelates which accounts it ≈øelfe to be Chri≈øts, and yet indeed is ≈øuch, as the Kings and Rulers of the Earth may and ought to ≈øuppre≈øse, and roote out of their dominions, is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
Such is their Mini≈øtery.
Therefore it is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy.

list.item: The A≈øsumption is proued in the former rea≈øon and in other Treati≈øes, and by ≈øome of them≈øelues in their Suites to Parlament, and if the Prelats and their conforming cleargy, deny it they are by their owne Canons excoÃÑmunicated ip≈øo facto.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: This ≈øixt Argument is borrowed from the fir≈øt Rea≈øon wher it is brought to proue that our Mini≈øtery is not the Mini≈øtery of Pa≈øtors and Teachers, as here it is brought againe to proue, that it is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy; Thus then hee rea≈øoneth, the King may and ought to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe this Mini≈øtery, Therfore it is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øy. But how doth hee proue, That the King ought to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe this Mini≈øtery? Hee refers vs for the proofe therof e≈øpecially to the former Rea≈øon, how doth hee proue it ther? Thus. It is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie. Therfore the king ought to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe it. Is not this learned ≈øtuffe?

Concerning his other Treati≈øes, which hee ≈øo often ≈øends vs vnto, as if they were in every ≈øtreete and market place of the lande, wee haue not ≈øo much idle time to ≈øeeke after them: and wee pre≈øume wee ≈øhall find noe better ≈øtuffe in them then in this; If any among≈øt vs haue put vp any ≈øuch ≈øuit to the Parlament, for the Abolli≈øhing of our Mini≈øtery in generall, let them an≈øwer for them≈øelues; But the Prelats may well laugh at his ≈øimplicity, and ≈øeeline≈ø≈øe of wit, that thinks to fright them with ≈øuch a bug-beare as this, in making them beleeue that they are by their owne Canons excommunicated
ip≈øo facto, if they deny that the King may, and ought to aboli≈øh our Mini≈øtery.

item.hi: If it bee ≈øuch as ≈øhall bee aboli≈øhed by the Lord throughout the power, and light of his Go≈øpell,
then is it the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
The fir≈øt is true.
Therfore the latter is true al≈øo.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: The ≈øame an≈øwer will ≈øerue to this Argument, that was giuen to the former; For the A≈ø≈øumption is fals, The light of the Go≈øpell ≈øhall more, and more, confirme e≈øtabli≈øh, and perfect it, and remoue all the defects and blemi≈øhes in it, his profe is as ridiculous, and ≈øophi≈øticall, as is the former; for hee proues it by the ≈øame que≈øtion, that here it is brought to proue, for ≈øo in effect proceeds his di≈øputation.

list.item: That which ≈øhall bee aboli≈øhed is Antichri≈øtian.
Our Mini≈øtery ≈øhall bee aboli≈øhed.
Ergo, It is Antichri≈øtian.

div.p: But how doth hee for our learning proue that our Mini≈øtery ≈øhall bee aboli≈øhed, very learnedly and profoundly thus.

list.item: That which is Antichri≈øtian ≈øhall be aboli≈øhed.
Our Mini≈øtery is Antichri≈øtian.
Therfore it ≈øhall be aboli≈øhed.

div.p: For this is the effect of that idle di≈øcour≈øe of 2. or 3. leaues, viz. pag. 46.-51. tending to proue, That Antichri≈øt, and all his offices ≈øhall be aboli≈øhed.
