item.hi: WHat ≈øoever Mini≈øtery is ≈øuch none can heare or haue any ≈øpirituall communion with it, but in ≈øo doing hee ≈øhall wor≈øhip the Image of the bea≈øt, and receaue his Marke, in his forehead or hand. That Mini≈øtery may none heare, or haue any ≈øpirituall communion with all.

But the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of England, is ≈øuch as none can heare or haue any ≈øpirituall Communion therwith but in ≈øo doing hee ≈øhall wor≈øhip the Bea≈øts image, and receaue his marke in his forehead or hand.

p.hi: None may heare or haue any Spirituall communion therwith.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: This Rea≈øon for the effect and ≈øub≈øtance therof differeth not from the ≈øeconde, for what is it (by his owne interpretation) to wor≈øhip the bea≈øts image, but to ≈øubiect him≈øelfe to the Mini≈øtery, and wor≈øhip of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie, and how is it po≈ø≈øible for him to proue this but by runing to the former Rea≈øons, for their help therin.

For the profe of the A≈ø≈øumption hee ≈øets vs downe a tedious and impertinent di≈øcours of ≈øome ≈øix leaues of paper, teaching what is meant by the bea≈øt & his Image,
and by receaving the marke in the forehead or hand, The ≈øome and effect wherof is this,

That by Bea≈øt wee are to vnder≈øtand the Romaine Dominion and Antichri≈øts hierarchie, withall the offices, lawes, Pag. 51.‚Äî63. and authority appertaining thervnto, That by wor≈øhipping the Bea≈øts Image may bee vnder≈øtoode the yealding of ≈øpirituall ≈øubiection to that Antichri≈øtian kingdome in the lawes offices and Iuri≈ødiction therof, That by receaving the marke in the forehead or hand, is publiquely to profe≈øse and ob≈øerue them not being a ≈øhamed of the bea≈øts wayes. And this doe all they who ≈øubmitte to the govermÃÑet of Prelats, Prie≈øts, Par≈øons, Vicars, booke wor≈øhip, &c. Not to contende about this interpretation, but to ≈øuppo≈øe it true, ther is nothing in ≈øub≈øtance here brought to confirme the 3. Rea≈øon, but that which is in the 2. Rea≈øon, viz. that therfore wee wor≈øhip the bea≈øt, in communicating with our Mini≈øtery, Becau≈øe it is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie. And therfore it needs noe other An≈øwer, then what hath bene giuen already. Only thus much further, That for men ≈øo far forth to ≈øubmit to the Gouerment of ≈øuch Prelats, &c. as our lawes doe require, is not to yealde ≈øpirituall ≈øubjection to the Kingdom of Antichri≈øte, nor without ≈øhame to profe≈ø≈øe the Bea≈øts wayes. For they may not with≈øtanding that bee ≈øubject to Chri≈øt and his lawes, and to fight again≈øt the bea≈øt. Yea though it ≈øhould be graunted, that ther, in ≈øundry perticulers they yeald to ≈øome things, in their v≈øe Antichri≈øtian and vnlawfull; which the be≈øt reformed Churches and Mini≈øters, ≈øometimes of ignorance or infirmity may doe; and yet remaine the Churches and Mini≈øtery of Chri≈øt.

item.hi: NOne may heare or joine in any Spirituall Communion with that Mini≈øtery which deriveth not their power and function of Mini≈øtery from Chri≈øt, which is the head for the edification of his Church, which is his body.
Such is the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of England.
Therfore none may heare or joyne in Spirituall Communion therwith.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: This rea≈øon is the ≈øame with the fir≈øt; for it is all one, To be derived from Chri≈øt, &, To be ≈øet by Chri≈øt in his Church, The other words which here hee addeth, Doth noe more vary the force of the Argument, then a new garment put vpon the ≈øame witne≈ø≈øe would make him a nue and different witne≈ø≈øe from him≈øelfe.
In the profe of the A≈ø≈øumption hee daubes 6. pages, bringing therin, nothing but his ould brokery, the ≈øub≈øtance wherof is as followeth.

item.hi: That our Mini≈øters haue not the≈øe offices which Chri≈øt hath giuen to his Church for the worke of his Mini≈øtery.
2. That it is the Mini≈øtery of Deacons and Prie≈øts made by the Prelats.

3. That they were left in England by the Pope, and are ≈øtill in the Kingdome of Antichri≈øt wher they fir≈øt ro≈øe, and theefore is devili≈øh, and by con≈øequent the more gifts and truth the Mini≈øters bring with them, the more the vphould the Mini≈øtery of iniquitie, and inti≈øse vnto their ≈øtolne waters and hid bread.

4. That our Church a≈øsemblies are not true vi≈øible Churches of Chri≈øt vn≈øeperated from the worlde not joyned together in Communion of the Go≈øpell by voluntary Profe≈øsion of the faith and ≈øubmi≈øsion to the Gouerment of Chri≈øt, but ≈øtanding in bondage vnto Antichri≈øt.

div.p: The very rehear≈øall of which rea≈øons is an≈øwer ≈øufficient, he being notable to proue, any of theis a≈ø≈øertions, but either by the A≈ø≈øumption it ≈øelfe, that they are brought to proue or one by another circularly; Contrarily I affirme.
1. That ther is no ordinary Mini≈øteriall office that Chri≈øt hath giuen vnto his Church, for the worke of his Mini≈øtery, but our Mini≈øters either haue or by our lawes ought to haue the ≈øame.
2. That it is a Mini≈øtery as oppo≈øite for the ≈øub≈øtaunce therof, to the Mini≈øtery of Popi≈øh, Prie≈øts, & Deacons, as light is oppo≈øit to darkne≈ø≈øe.

3. That the Pope left not ≈øuch Prie≈øts, and Deacons as ours are, nor hath any ≈øuch in his Kingdome; But that our Prie≈øts and Deacons, haue bene vnder God and the Prince, the principall Per≈øons that haue driuen, the Pope and his Prie≈øts and Deacons, out of the Realme; That it is devili≈øh for any to ≈øay that they are devili≈øh except they can proue it by better rea≈øons. That they that haue the be≈øt gifts, doe not intice any to ≈øtolne waters, or hidden bread, or to vphould any Mi≈øtery of
iniquitie; Except the Go≈øpell of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and the true and onely meanes of ≈øalvation; bee the Mi≈øtery of iniquitie.

4. That our Church A≈ø≈øemblies being ≈øuch as by the lawes of the land they ought to bee; are ≈øo far forth ≈øeperated from the world, joyned together in the communion of the Go≈øpell, by the voluntary profe≈ø≈øion of faith, &c. and freed from Antichri≈øt, as is ≈øufficient to make them true vi≈øible Churches of Chri≈øt, notwith≈øtanding that many things may bee wanting, to the full and de≈øired perfection of them. And I doubt not but wee ≈øhall bee far more able at any time by rea≈øon out of Gods worde, to proue theis points, then ever M. Iohn≈øon will bee to proue the contrary. And yet it were ea≈øie to proue any thing, by ≈øuch a jugling Method of Rea≈øoning, as M. Iohn≈øon hath gotten; For hee can proue you the 1. Rea≈øon by the 2, the 2. by the 1. The 3. by the 1. and 2, the 1. and 2. by the 3. The 4. by the 1.2. & 3. and every of them by the 4. and all 4. by that que≈øtion which here they are brought to proue.

item.hi: NOne may heare or haue any Spirituall communion with tho≈øe Mini≈øters, which Mini≈øter the holy things of God, and worke vpon the Con≈øciences of men, by vertue of a fals Spirituall calling.
Such are the Mini≈øters of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande.

p.hi: None may heare or haue any Spirituall communion with them.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: This Argument which here hee brings again≈øt our Mini≈øtery, is the very ≈øame with the 2. For by a fals Spirituall calling, hee meanes a calling proceeding from the Apo≈øta≈øie of Antichri≈øt.

The Prepo≈øition for brevitie ≈øake hee proues by fiue and thirtie places of Scripture: And yet who ≈øoeuer ≈øhall pleas to take the paines to examine them, ≈øhall finde, that nether ≈øeverally nor joyntly, they proue the ≈øame.

The A≈ø≈øumption wheron the whole weight of the controver≈øie, leaneth, hee proueth onely by the fir≈øt Argument, wherby hee proued the A≈ø≈øumption of the 2.
Rea≈øon viz. Becau≈øe they doe it by vertue of their Mini≈øtery receaved of their Prelats, from their Spirituall Authority, which is v≈øurped and Antichri≈øtian; And this is all this witne≈ø≈øe hath to ≈øay; and all the an≈øwer it needeth; Onely hee wandreth into certaine objections, and queries, grounded vpon ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øed defences of ≈øome of our Mini≈øters; Vnto which I will (though I neede not) giue a breif an≈øwer from point to point.
div.q: Obj. Some ≈øay they preach not by vertue of their Mini≈øtery taken from the Prelats, but by vertue of ≈øome other calling and Authority.
div.p: An≈ø. I knowe none hauing receaued ordination from the Prelats, that neede deny that they preach partly by vertue of the Mini≈øtery which they haue taken from them; Noe though they hould the calling of Prelates vnlawfull: For what is the Mini≈øtery which they haue taken from them, for the ≈øub≈øtance therof. But (after a triall of their gifts) a libertie, and leaue graunted vnto them to preach the worde of God, and admini≈øter the Sacraments, in ≈øuch Congregations as they ≈øhall bee called vnto.
div.q: Obj. Why will ≈øuch ≈øeeme to renounce that calling, receaued of the Prelats, and yet blame vs for doing the like.
div.p:
An≈ø. They may acknowledge a further calling, then that of the Prelats, and yet not therin renounce the calling receaved from the Prelates, but rather ratifie the ≈øame; For the Prelats being learned divines, and having approued of their gifts, and by words, and letters Te≈øtimoniall giuen, libertie to execute the Mini≈øtery of the Go≈øpell; they doe not therby thru≈øt them into a Mini≈øtery, but they leaue them to bee further called or cho≈øen,
either by the people, or tho≈øe Patrons, vnto who≈øe fidelitie the people haue committed this charge: And therfore this acknowledging of a further calling, maketh nothing to the ju≈øtification of the proude & ignorant ≈øchi≈øm of this Per≈øons.
div.q: Obj. If they preach by virtue of another calling how then ≈øtande they Mini≈øters of that Church wher noe other is alowed, and how impo≈øe they them≈øelues vpon any of their Pari≈øhe A≈øsemblies, ≈øeing the lawes of the land allow onely the Prelacie, Prie≈øthood, and Deaconry a fore≈øaide,
div.p: An≈ø. Though this ≈øhould be graunted (which hee in his ignoraÃÑt ≈øimplicitie doth ≈øuppo≈øe) that ≈øome among≈øt vs, hauing bene ordained by the Prelates did exerci≈øe our Mini≈øtery, by virtue of another calling, and though the law of the land, alow noe other, yet (e≈øpecially ≈øo long as they are permitted to execute their Mini≈øtery by tho≈øe in Authority, though it bee by virtue of another calling) they are to bee reputed Mini≈øters of that Church, that hath v≈øe of their Mini≈øtery.
div.q: Obj. How al≈øo herein can they avoide to bee both intruders and hipocrits, intruders in taking vpon them≈øelues a publique office in that Church again≈øt the publique lawes and con≈øtitutions therof, hipocrits, becau≈øe they pretend in ≈øhew one thing to the Prince, and State, and yet performe another indeede.
div.p:
An≈ø. All theis inferences are vpon a fals ≈øuppo≈øition; yet if there were any ≈øuch Per≈øons, they could noe more therin bee ≈øaid to bee intruders, and hipocrits then they of the Seperation are; For though the publique lawes ≈øhould bee again≈øt any other calling, yet ≈øo long as they take an office by a good calling, they cannot bee ≈øaid to
intrude them≈øelues. Nether doe any ≈øuch among≈øt vs (if ther bee any ≈øuch) pretend in ≈øhew any more then they doe indeed performe, for ≈øo far forth as any differ in iudgement from the publique lawes, of the State, they are ready to profe≈ø≈øe it, being called thervnto, and they practis onely that, which they iudge lawfull, being as ready, as any of the ≈øeperatioÃÑ to ≈øuffer, rather then practis approue, or a≈ø≈øent vnto any thing, which they judge vnlawfull, and vnwarrantable.

Obj. But ≈øuppo≈øe they had ≈øome other lawfull calling yet they al≈øo retaining this vnlawfull calling of the Prelats this were but to halt betweene two opinions, and to ≈øet their thre≈øhould by Gods thre≈øhoulds and their po≈øts by Gods po≈øts.

An≈ø. How can ≈øuch bee ≈øaid to retaine the vnlawfull calling of the Prelats, which prote≈øt again≈øt the ≈øame, & profe≈ø≈øe that they preach not by that, but by another calling? But if ther bee any ≈øuch, that exerci≈øe their Mini≈øtery by another calling be≈øids that of the Prelats, they therin refu≈øe; obeidience, and conformitie to what ≈øoever in the Prelats calling they judge vnlawfull, and ≈øo doe not joyne an vnlawfull and a lawfull calling together, but reject the corruptions, retaine the good, and ≈øupplie the defect with another calling; and this is the wor≈øte that can bee made of it; But this is not to joyne mans Tre≈øhoulds to Gods, &c. but clean contrary, to ≈øeperate them, as much as may bee; And how can they bee ≈øaide to halt betweene two opinions, when ≈øo far onely as the truth (in their iudgement and opinion) is e≈øtabli≈øhed by publique lawes they imbrace it, acknowledging their ≈øubjection to the ≈øame lawes, and contrarily, wher they judge that the law ≈øwerves from the
truth, they take another cour≈øe, But ≈øtill hee begs this, (which is the maine controver≈øie) that our Mini≈øters haue receaued an vnlawfull calling from the Prelates.

In the next place hee labors to proue by rea≈øons that how≈øoever ≈øome pretend another calling, yet it is evident, that the execute all the duties of their Mini≈øteries, by virtue of their calling taken from their Prelats; But what of that; This will ≈øtand him in noe ≈øteed, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee given him of almes. That every Mini≈øtery executed by virtue of a calling taken from the Prelats, is an vnlawfull and an Antichri≈øtian Mini≈øterie; For proue it hee cannot, And if wee ≈øhould, except this al≈øo bee given him, That our Mini≈øtery is executed ONLY by virtue of a calling taken from the Prelats; and not by any other power, or virtue be≈øids, taken either from God or man. But let vs ≈øee his rea≈øons.

p.hi: 1. They cannot ≈øtand publique Mini≈øters except they receaue of the Prelats the Prie≈øthood and Deaconry a fore≈øaid.

div.p: 2. They are excommunicated ip≈øo facto, if they affirme that they whoe are made Bi≈øhops, Deacons, and Prie≈øts, are not lawfully made, vntill thie haue ≈øome other calling.

p.hi: 3. The people haue not the liberty of the Churches of Chri≈øt nor power in this their e≈øtate to cho≈øe and ≈øubmit vnto the true and lawfull Mini≈øtery appointed by Chri≈øt.
4. Without and again≈øt the peoples con≈øent, they are by the Prelats a lone ≈øilenced, depriued, and degraded from exerci≈øiing any Mini≈øtery in tho≈øe A≈øsemblies.

div.p:
Theis rea≈øons doe not proue, That they exerci≈øe their mini≈øtery ONLY by virtue of a calling receaved froÃÑ the
Prelats, and therfore whether true or fals are nothing to the purpo≈øe, and vnworthy any further An≈øwer.

After this hee fetcheth another Rode out, and laboureth to proue, that our Mini≈øters ought not to ≈øuffer them≈øelues to bee ≈øilenced, and depo≈øed from their publique Mini≈øtery, no not by lawfull Magi≈øtrats, which is not onely fals and ≈øeditious; as ≈øhall appeare afterwarde, but idle and impertinent, to the pre≈øent controver≈øie, for if it were true that Mini≈øters ought not to doe in this ca≈øe, as ours doe; yet this doth not argue, any corruption in the calling of their Mini≈øtery, but a weackne≈ø≈øe onely in the Per≈øons that execute it, in yealding further from their owne right, then they neede to doe; But let vs con≈øider the perticulers, that hee objecteth again≈øt our Mini≈øters in this re≈øpect.

Obj. The Apo≈øtles being true Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt would not at the commandement of lawfull Magi≈øtrats, leaue to preach, much le≈øse ≈øhould true Mini≈øters, at the appointement of v≈øurping Prelats. Nether did the Apo≈øtles make, their imediate calling from God the ground of their refu≈øall, but this, That they ought to obey God rather then man, which is a duty required of all Mini≈øters and Chri≈øtians.

An≈ø. 1. Wher hee di≈øtingui≈øheth between ≈øilencing, & depriving, by Prelats and lawfull Magi≈øtrats, it is in our ca≈øe, wher the Prelats doe it by Authority, and commi≈ø≈øion from lawfull Magi≈øtrats; a di≈øtinction without a difference. 2. Though the Apo≈øtles did not a≈ø≈øigne, their imidiate calling from God, as the ground of their refu≈øall, in ≈øo many letters, and ≈øillables, yet that which they doe a≈ø≈øigne, is by implication, and in effect the ≈øame with it; for it is as much as if they had ≈øaid; God him≈øelfe
hath impo≈øed this calling vpon vs, and not man; & therfore except wee ≈øhould rather obey man, then God, wee may not forbeare, this office, which hee hath impo≈øed vpon vs. For oppo≈øing the obeidience of God to the obeidience of man, hee therin pleads a calling from God; and not from man: otherwi≈øe if they had receaved a calling from man, there had bene incongruitie in the an≈øwer, con≈øidering that in common ≈øence and rea≈øon, they ought ≈øo far forth to obey men, forbidding them to exerci≈øe a calling, as they exerci≈øe the ≈øame by virtue of that calling els by this rea≈øon, A Mini≈øter ≈øhould not ceas to preach, vpon the commandemeÃÑt of the Church, that hath cho≈øen him, but ≈øhould be bound to giue them al≈øo the ≈øame an≈øwer which they Apo≈øtles gaue, which were ab≈øurd. So that by this gro≈ø≈øe conceit of M. Iohn≈øons, their ≈øhould bee no power, in any ≈øort of men whom≈øoever, to depo≈øe a Mini≈øter from his Mini≈øtery, but that notwith≈øtaÃÑding any comandement: of Church or State the Mini≈øter is to continue in his Mini≈øtery. But for the further an≈øwer of this his ignorant conceit plainly tending to ≈øedition, wee are to know; That though the Apo≈øtles, Prophets, and Euangeli≈øts, preached publiquely where they were not hindred by open violence, And did not, nor might not leaue their Mini≈øtery vpon any humain Authoritie and commandement what≈øoever; becau≈øe they did not enter into or exerci≈øe the ≈øame, vpon the will, and plea≈øure of any man what≈øoever; yet they never erected and planted publique Churches and Mini≈øteries in the face of the Magi≈øtrate, whether they would or noe, or in di≈øpite of them. But ≈øuch in re≈øpect of the eye of the Magi≈øtrat, were as private
and invi≈øible as might bee: Neither were ≈øome of the Apo≈øtles onely forbidden, ≈øo as others ≈øhould bee ≈øuffered to preach the ≈øame Gho≈øpel in their places: but the vtter aboli≈øhing of Chri≈øtian Religion was manife≈øtly intended in the ≈øilencing of them. But our Churches wherof wee are Mini≈øters, are noe private & ≈øecreat A≈ø≈øemblies, ≈øuch as hide them≈øelues from the face of a per≈øecuting Magi≈øtrat, and State. But are publique profe≈ø≈øing their wor≈øhip, & doing their religion in the face of the Magi≈øtrate and State, yea and by his contenance, authoritie and protection; And wee are ≈øet over tho≈øe Churches, not onely by a calling of our people, but al≈øo by the authoritie of the Magi≈øtrate who hath an armed power to hinder any ≈øuch publique Action: who is willing al≈øo to permitte and maintaine other true Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpel in tho≈øe places where hee forbiddeth ≈øome. If therfore after our publique calling, to Mini≈øter to ≈øuch a knowne and publique Church, but by the Magi≈øtrat al≈øo, The Magi≈øtrate ≈øhall haue matter again≈øt vs, (whether ju≈øt or inju≈øt it skilleth not) and ≈øhall in that regard forbid vs to Mini≈øter to our Church. I ≈øee not by what warrant in Gods word, wee ≈øhould thinke our ≈øelues bounde not with≈øtanding to exerci≈øe our Mini≈øtery ≈øtill; Except wee ≈øhould thinke ≈øuch a law of Mini≈øtery to ly vpon vs, that wee ≈øhould judge our ≈øelues bound, to run vpon the ≈øword point of the Magi≈øtrate or to oppo≈øe ≈øword to ≈øworde. It being not the v≈øe of the higher powers, in ≈øuch ca≈øes nakedly to forbid, but to ≈øet a ≈øword to the brea≈øt, therby to force them, which ≈øhall refu≈øe. And ≈øuppo≈øe the Magi≈øtrate ≈øhould
doe it inju≈øtly, and again≈øt the will of the Church, and ≈øhould therin ≈øinne; yet doth not the Church, in that regard ceas to bee a Church, nor ought ≈øhee therin to re≈øi≈øt the will of the Magi≈øtrate; Nether doth ≈øhee ≈øtand bound in regard of her affection to her Mini≈øter (how great and de≈øerved ≈øoever) to deprive her ≈øelfe of the protection of the Magi≈øtrat, by leauing her publique ≈øtanding to follow her Mini≈øtery in private and the darke; refu≈øing the benefit of all other publique Mini≈øtery, which with the leaue and liking of the Magi≈øtrate ≈øhee may injoy; Nether doe I knowe what warrant any ordinarie Mini≈øter hath by Gods worde in ≈øuch a Ca≈øe ≈øo to draw any ≈øuch Church or people to his private Mini≈øtery, that therby they ≈øhould hazzard their outward ≈øtate and quiet in the Common wealth wher they liue, when in ≈øome competent Mea≈øure they may publiquely, with the grace and fauours of the Magi≈øtrat, inioy the ordinarie meanes of their Salvation, by another, (and except hee haue a calling to Mini≈øter to ≈øome other Church) to bee content to live as a private member, till it ≈øhould plea≈øe God to reconcile the Magi≈øtrate vnto him, and ≈øo call him againe to his owne Church, laboring in meane while, privately vpon perticuler occa≈øions offred, to ≈øtrengthen and cofirme, in the wayes of God tho≈øe people that are deprived of his publique labours, and I take it to bee the dutie, of the people in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, if they will approue
them≈øelues, faithfull Chri≈øtians, and good Subjects, ≈øo to ≈øubmit to the Mini≈øtery of another, as that by prayer and all other good dutifull and loyall meanes, they may doe their be≈øt indevour to obtaine him of whom again≈øt their will, they haue bene deprived and ≈øtill to affect and loue him as their Pa≈øtor. Now if the people doe thus, then is that Mini≈øter called to bee ≈øilent not onely by the Magi≈øtrate, but by them al≈øo, though with much greife.
Obj. It is the dutie of all Mini≈øters, and Chri≈øtians as will as Apo≈øtles, to obey God, and not man, when man forbiddeth that which God commandeth, or commandeth that which God forbiddeth.

An≈ø. True, but God noe wher that I can find, commaundeth either a Mini≈øter to Mini≈øter publiquely in a publique Church maintained by the Magi≈øtrate, again≈øt the will, and in de≈øpite of the Magi≈øtrate, noe more then again≈øt the will and in de≈øpite of the Church it ≈øelfe.

Obj. Vriah at the commaundement of the King made an Alter after the fa≈øhion of that of Dama≈øcus but therin ≈øinned, though hee offred theron ≈øuch burnt-offrings as God had appointed; much le≈øse may the Mini≈øtery vnder the Go≈øpell, bee framed after any nue manner devi≈øed by man lea≈øt of all after Antichri≈øt, though in that Mini≈øtery many doctrines of the Go≈øpell bee taught, and ≈øuch Sacraments admini≈øtred as God hath ordained.

An≈ø. This Example of Vriah the Prie≈øt is altogether impertinent, vnto that which goeth before. It being one thing vpon the commaundement of the Magi≈øtrate to forbeare the publique exerci≈øe of a true Mini≈øtery, another thing vpon his commaundement to frame a nue
Mini≈øtery after a nue manner devized by man or Antichri≈øt.

After this hee runs out of his way againe to ≈øatisfie an objection, that hee had propounded and indevoured (as far as his learning would giue him leaue) to an≈øwer before; And which doth nothing at all depend vpon any thing that goeth before in this Argument, wherin hee re≈øembles ≈øome wanton Curs, that takes delight to turne round about to catch their owne tailes; But let vs ≈øee what it is hee ≈øaith.

Obj. Here againe concerning ≈øuch as plead that they teach the truth, and many excellent points of Doctrine. It is to bee ob≈øerved, that yet none may therfore heare their Mini≈øtery vnder Coler of learning the truth becau≈øe in yealding to receaue and heare it from Antichri≈øts Mini≈øtery, They defile the Temple of God, and become the Subjects of Antichri≈øt, pag. 75.

An≈ø. Wher hee againe, taketh it as matter that mu≈øt whether wee will or noe, bee graunted vnto him, That our Mini≈øtery is Antichri≈øts Mini≈øtery, which needs noe other an≈øwer then before, yet thus much further. 1. That noe Mini≈øtery what≈øoever (≈øo far forth as it teacheth the truth of Chri≈øt e≈øpecially a truth oppo≈øite to the doctrine of Antichri≈øt) is the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øt; And tho≈øe which ≈øhall ≈øubmit and ≈øubject them≈øelues vnto any Mini≈øtery what≈øoever, onely ≈øo far forth as they Mini≈øter and teach ≈øuch truth, cannot therin bee ≈øaid to defile the Temple of God, or to bee Subjects of Antichri≈øt, but bee obedient to Ie≈øus Chri≈øt.

2. Our Mini≈øtery in divers Congregations of the land at the lea≈øt, Teach not onely many excellent points of doctrin.
But ≈øo much doctrine as is ≈øufficient to the Salvation of him that beleeueth the ≈øame; even all the maine fundamentall points of Salvation clearly ≈øet downe in Gods word; yea and for ought any can proue to the countrary. All other le≈ø≈øe nece≈ø≈øary points, ≈øo far forth, as God hath revealed, and convinced their con≈øciences of the truth of them.

3. Tho≈øe among≈øt vs who make con≈øcience of hearing our Mini≈øtery, doe not heare them vnder a Colour of learning the truth, but onely to this very end, and purpo≈øe, that they might learne the truth, and therin the true way of ≈øerving and wor≈øhipping God according to his owne will.

Obj. And not to ≈øpeake of the many errors & fal≈øhoods which they al≈øo teach, it is no nue thing that the Mini≈øters of Antichri≈øt, ≈øhould in diuers things teach and bring the truth with them, for when Sathan cannot by fal≈øhood vtter his wares, ordinaunces, Mini≈øtery wor≈øhip, hee will bee glad to vtter the ≈øame by teaching the truth. pag. 75.76.

An≈ø. 1. Our Errors whether for weight or member, or qualitie, are not ≈øuch, ≈øo great, ≈øo many, but they may be fall vnto true Chri≈øtians, whether Mini≈øters or people, yea (as M. Iohn≈øon well knoweth) many of the Martyrs of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, haue liued and died, in more and greater Errors of the ≈øame kinde, and therfore well may hee pa≈ø≈øe by this point. This is but a peece of his ≈øimple thetoricke, carele≈øly to ≈øeeme to pa≈ø≈øe by that which hee cannot proue. For how many Errors, can hee name or number, that hee is able to ju≈øtify to be taught in the Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies? what one truth of Religion can hee name, that is not or hath not bene
(when ju≈øt occa≈øion hath bene offred) taught by ≈øome of our Mini≈øters? I am not ignorant that in his treati≈øes again≈øt M. A. H. and M. H. I. hee mu≈øtreth a whole troup of pretended Errors, but ≈øuppo≈øe them to bee ≈øo many de≈øtinct Errors, how doth hee proue they are taught in our Mini≈øtery or that they are required by law to bee taught? Ther is indeed a Conformitie and Sub≈øcription required to ≈øome of them, and a Canon that requires that the late Canons bee reade in Churches ≈øome times in the yeare, as al≈øo that the booke of Articles bee read at the fir≈øt entrance vpon an Eccle≈øia≈øtical Church, with a te≈øtification of a≈ø≈øent vnto it: But is this Mini≈øterially to teach the Errors contained in the ≈øaid bookes? May not a man in the weackne≈ø≈øe of his judgement, and in infirmitie at his fir≈øt entrance into a calling, conforme and ≈øub≈øcribe vnto ≈øome things, not ≈øo warantable, and true, and yet not teach them for truths; yea may hee not, for all that teach doctrin in it ≈øelfe directly countrary to tho≈øe vntruths, yea and yet ≈øatisfie al≈øo the minde of the law, which being humaine, and therfore not alwaies perfect, may commaunde that very truth to bee taught, which being thorowly followed, will de≈øtroy ≈øome vntruths, which the ≈øame law al≈øo requires? Further it is one thing to reade the Canons to the people, therby to declare vnto them what is required at their hands, by their Governors, another thing to teach, and ju≈øtifie the Errors countained in them, and to te≈øtifie an a≈ø≈øent vnto ≈øome Errors, is not Mini≈øterially to in≈øtruct the people in tho≈øe Errors.

2. Though it bee noe nue thing that the Mini≈øters of Antichri≈øt, ≈øhould in divers things bring the truth with them; Yet this is a nue thing and never hard of before, That the Mini≈øters of Antichri≈øt, ≈øhould teach the wholl truth of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus for the ≈øub≈øtaÃÑce therof. That they ≈øhould oppo≈øe directly and zealou≈øly again≈øt the maine, and foundamentall doctrins of Antichri≈øt; That they ≈øhould profe≈ø≈øe him to bee Antichri≈øt, and that man of ≈øinne, and to the ≈øheeding of their blood, ≈øhould exerci≈øe their Mini≈øtery again≈øt Antichri≈øt and his kingdome, prote≈øting again≈øt him and his Service, were it not nue ≈øtraunge that a man ≈øhould bee counted a true Subject vnto a Prince, then when hee doth openly prote≈øt again≈øt him. Counting him a v≈øurping Tirant, and imploying all the wit power and ≈øtrength hee hath again≈øt him? ≈øuch ≈øubjects of Antichri≈øt are our Mini≈øters, or by the lawes ≈øuch they ought to bee. Could hee bee ≈øaid to bee a Mini≈øter of Chri≈øt, that yealding to ≈øome externall kites, and profe≈ø≈øing ≈øome doctrines of Chri≈øtian faith, doth not with≈øtanding, directly, openly and profe≈ø≈øedly, renounce Chri≈øt and his Seruice, and profe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe to bee an enemie to him, and his Kingdome, If it hould not in the one, it is not both a nue and ≈øtrang thing that it ≈øhould hould in the other.

3. M. Iohn≈øon out of his knowledge mu≈øt teach vs; how Sathan can be ≈øaid, by teaching the truth to vtter his owne Mini≈øtery, or wor≈øhip, or how a Sathanicall Mini≈øtery can be vttered when in and by the Mini≈øtery, nothing but the truth of Chri≈øt is admini≈øtred; what is the Mini≈øtery of Sathan but the Mini≈øtery of Error? how can the Mini≈øtery of Error bee vttered by teaching
the Truth? or how can a Mini≈øtery be ≈øaid to be vttered, by a truth, when it is the Mini≈øtery it ≈øelfe that vttereth the truth, Surely noe more then a Marchandize can bee ≈øaid to bee vttered by ≈øelling of wares, and were it not a wonder, if a man ≈øhould vtter his bad Marchandice, by ≈øelling good & ≈øound wares? Sathan and Antichri≈øt indeed together with ≈øome truths, ≈øeeke to vtter much fal≈øhoode, which otherwi≈øe (they knowe) would not be receaued: And many of our Mini≈øters are content to yeald to ≈øome things which they judge not ≈øo counvenient (if it did otherwi≈øe ≈øome good to the State) to the end they may vtter the truth. But that like Antichri≈øt and Sathan our Mini≈øters ≈øhould propound this vnto them≈øelues, to teach ≈øome truths to this end that they might, therby vtter fal≈øhood and lies, fals Mini≈øteries & wor≈øhips is a Malitious imputation, and can never bee ju≈øtified.

Obj. Beza ≈øaith, Though Antichri≈øt teach the truth (which ≈øometimes hee doth) to the end hee may more ea≈øily ≈øeduce to beleeue his lies, yet wee are to ≈øtoppe our eares again≈øt him, lea≈øt vnder his pretence, wee bee deceaved by him. pag. 76.

An≈ø. Well, but it is yet to proue, That our Mini≈øters are Antichri≈øts, and that they teach the truth to any ≈øuch wicked intent; the contrary is manife≈øt, when many of them in regard of the times, are countent, to yealde to ≈øome colourable vntruths, that they might therby purcha≈øe libertie vnto them≈øelues, to aduance the truth of Chri≈øt, They yeald to ≈øome things in appearance Antichri≈øtian, that they might with more libertie fight again≈øt Antichri≈øt.

Obj. Who knoweth not that Antichri≈øt and his Mini≈øters
are hipocriticall frends to Chri≈øt vnder the name of Chri≈øt fighting again≈øt him.

An≈ø. But who knoweth not that our Mini≈øters, if they bee ≈øuch as our lawes require them to bee, are ≈øworn enemies to Antichri≈øt, and in the name of Chri≈øt, and vnder ≈øome of Antichri≈øts owne Rites doe fight again≈øt him and re≈øi≈øt him vnto blood; And who knoweth not, that many of them haue died for Chri≈øt at the foot of Antichri≈øt.

item.hi: IF the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church of Englande bee a ≈øtrange Mini≈øtery, then is it not lawfull in the wor≈øhip of God, to heare it, or haue any Spirituall communion therwith.
But ≈øuch is the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of England.
Therfore it is not lawfull in the wor≈øhip of God to heare it, or haue any Spirituall Communion therwith.

The A≈øsumption is manife≈øt, for a ≈øtrange Mini≈øtery is that which is not by the law ordained, and giuen for that worke, as them≈øelues here to fore haue publi≈øhed, and as is proued in the fir≈øt Rea≈øon.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
This Rea≈øon differreth not in ≈øub≈øtance from divers of the former, for what is it to bee a ≈øtrang Mini≈øtery, but to be a Mini≈øtery that is not ≈øet by Chri≈øt in his Church
which is his 1. Rea≈øon. But to bee a Mini≈øtery which deriveth not the power and function from Chri≈øt, which is his 4. Rea≈øon. But to bee a Mini≈øtery that worketh vpon mens con≈øciences by virtue of a fals Spirituall calling which is his 5. Rea≈øon. Might hee not with as greate facility out of this method of rea≈øoning haue brought forth 7000. Rea≈øons as theis ≈øeaven. But how doth hee proue the A≈ø≈øumption of his rea≈øon? by ≈øending vs back againe (as you may ≈øee) to the fir≈øt Rea≈øon. So that all the rea≈øon of this Rea≈øon is borrowed from the 1. Rea≈øon and is an≈øwered all ready in the An≈øwer therof.

But before hee pa≈ø≈øeth to the next rea≈øon, hee runs out after the wonted fa≈øhion, into an idle di≈øcours, nothing at all appertaining to the Argument in hand, bringing in ≈øome idle ob≈øervations vpon the Story of Corah, Dathan, and Abiram, & al≈øo of Naaman, fal≈øly Mi≈øapplied vnto our Church A≈ø≈øemblies & Mini≈øtery. For hee taking it as graunted, or as a thing that could not be denied him, That our Mini≈øtery is Antichri≈øtian, & that our wor≈øhip is Idolatry, hee makes our Mini≈øters, & people even the be≈øt of them wors then Corah, Dathan, & Abiram and them which were of their con≈øpiracy, and our A≈ø≈øemblies and wor≈øhip as bad as the Temple of Rimmon, and the idolatry therin performed. And wher hee brings the example of Naaman, as brought by ≈øome of vs to ju≈øtifie our joining with our Church A≈ø≈øemblies I per≈øuade my ≈øelfe he doth again≈øt the knowledge and light of his owne con≈øcience bely vs; & that ther cannot be one of vs brought forth, that ever made this plea; we hould it as vnlawful (as them≈øelues) outwardly & but in appearance to joyne with Idolators, in their Idolatry: &
wee ≈øee noe warrant why for every perticuler Act, that in a large ≈øence is Idolatrous, adjoined to Gods true wor≈øhip, wee ≈øhould forbeare our pre≈øence, at the true wor≈øhip it ≈øelfe. Or that our pre≈øence, for the true wor≈øhips ≈øake alone, ≈øhould in re≈øpect of ≈øome point of fal≈øe wor≈øhip thervnto a nexed bee (as hee ≈øpeaketh) the ≈øubmitting our bodies to a ≈øtrang wor≈øhip. E≈øpecially when wee are not perticuler Actors in it, but onely pre≈øent, behoulding it with greife, and ≈øuffering it in others for the true wor≈øhip ≈øake vnto which it is adjoined, If this ≈øhould bee held vnlawfull; then can noe man pre≈øent him≈øelf with a good con≈øcience, at any publique wor≈øhip of God wher≈øoever. Becau≈øe (except it ≈øhould be ≈øtinted and pre≈øcribed, which M. Iohn≈øon holds to bee a fals wor≈øhip) hee can haue noe a≈ø≈øeurance, but that ≈øome errors in matter or forme will bee committed; yea if hee bee a man of vnder≈øtanding, and learning, hee may pre≈øume in a maÃÑner, that in the publique wor≈øhip, ≈øome error or other in matter or forme, greater or le≈ø≈øer will bee committed, before which he mu≈øt pre≈øent him≈øelfe. But what? were the Iewi≈øh Sinagoges in Chri≈øts time free from all parts of fals wor≈øhip? the Scripture witne≈ø≈øeth the contrary. Did they when Chri≈øt came into them, for beare their A≈ø≈øemblies? The Scripture confirmes the contrary, was Chri≈øt pre≈øence then (as heere he ≈øaith our pre≈øence is) a very bowing downe vnto them? was hee al≈øo therin an vncon≈øcionable di≈øsembler. Did hee therin imbrace the bo≈øome of Strangers? breake his couenant, goe a whoreing with the inventions of man. For (≈øuch fiere as this hee ≈øpits at vs) if not, why ≈øhould it bee ≈øuch a ≈øin in vs? who haue not ≈øuch eyes to pearce into the impiety of mans traditions, as our Saviour had.

item.hi: IF the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church of Englande bee not from Heaven, but of men, then is it not lawfull in the wor≈øhip of God to heare or haue any Spirituall Communion therwith.

list.item: Such is the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande. Ergo, It is not lawfull in the wor≈øhip of God to haue any Spirituall communion therwith.

item.hi: The A≈øsumption is evident, becau≈øe God hath not appointed the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies, but man, as appeares by their booke or ordination, And if they will ≈øay the contrary, let them≈øhew their callings out of the word of God.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: This Rea≈øon is the very ≈øame with the 4.5. and 6. and hath noe ground, or profe but from them: And therfore is An≈øwered al≈øo in the An≈øwer of them. And this may bee ≈øufficient to ≈øhew, that our Mini≈øtery is from Heaven, when ≈øo malitious, and excerci≈øed an Adver≈øary who≈øe whole Religion ≈øeemes to lie in oppo≈øing to our Mini≈øtery, can ≈øay noe more again≈øt it.

div.head: THE SECOND SORT OF REASONS TAKEN AS is pretended forth of our owne Writers. EXAMINED.
THE FIRST ARGVMENT TAKEN from the twelue Arguments. EXAMINED.

item.hi: AL will-wor≈øhip is Sinne.
To heare or communicate with the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande, in Church Service in manner and forme pre≈øcribed, is a will-wor≈øhip.
Therfore to heare or communicate with that Mini≈øtery is Sinne.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
This Sillogi≈øme is Sophi≈øticall, con≈øi≈øting plainely of foure termes, Except hee make his conclu≈øion this. Ther fore to heare or communicate with that Mini≈øtery in manner
and forme pre≈øcribed is a Sinne. For the third Argument being wil-wor≈øhip. Al the other terms they being no parts therof, mu≈øt bee in the conclu≈øion: If ≈øo bee the ≈øillogi≈øme bee true as every Sophoming boy, in the vniver≈øitie knoweth: And therfore hee mu≈øt either exclude them out of the A≈ø≈øumption, or include them in the conclu≈øion, which hee cannot doe, it being his intent, by theis Arguments to proue it a ≈øinne to communicate therwith not onely in manner or forme pre≈øcribed, but any other way, And therfore hee Sophi≈øtically, or rather in ignorant and witle≈ø≈øe ≈øimplicity, concluds a generall from a Speciall thus,
It is a will-wor≈øhip to communicate with our Mini≈øtery in manner and forme pre≈øcribed.
Therfore it is a ≈øinne to communicate therwith whether in manner or forme pre≈øcribed or any other way.

Wheras a Childe may knowe this, That an Action donne in ≈øome manner and forme pre≈øcribed may bee a will-wor≈øhip and a ≈øinne, which donne otherwi≈øe may bee true wor≈øhip; A man may therfore (if neede bee) graunt both his premi≈øes and deny his conclu≈øion. Nether will it help him, that the Author of the 12. Arguments, concluded again≈øt the Ceremonies, in the ≈øame forme of words, that hee doth here again≈øt the Mini≈øtery, It being plain by the ≈øcope of his wholl di≈øputation, That though hee do not expre≈ø≈øe tho≈øe words in manner and forme pre≈øcribed, in the conclu≈øion; That yet hee vnder≈øtandeth them, It being not his purpo≈øe to di≈øpute ab≈øolutely again≈øt all v≈øe of them, but again≈øt the v≈øe of them, in that manner and forme that they are pre≈øcribed.

But what≈øoever his Conclu≈øion is, The A≈ø≈øumption is fals, yea though it ≈øhould bee graunted that in our Mini≈øtery ther is ≈øome will-wor≈øhip performed; yet let vs ≈øee how hee proues the A≈ø≈øumption.

item.hi: All parts of divine wor≈øhip and Service impo≈øed onely by the will and plea≈øure of man vpon the Communicants in divine ≈øervice and that of nece≈øsitie to bee donne, is will-wor≈øhip.

But to heare and Communicate, with the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Eugland, in Church Service in manner and forme pre≈øcribed, are ≈øuch parts of divine wor≈øhip, as is a fore≈øaid.

p.hi: To heare and Communicate with the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈ø≈øemblies of England in manner and forme pre≈øcribed is a will-wor≈øhip.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: The Propo≈øition is taken forth of the 12. Argumentes and therfore needs noe An≈øwer.

The A≈ø≈øumption is fals, But hee proueth it thus,
1. Man impo≈øeth this Mini≈øtery vpon man, and God in his word hath not appointed the≈øe offices and Callings, Nether required any to communicate with them in Church Service in manner and forme pre≈øcribed.
And 2. the people ≈øtand bound to heare, and communicate with them vpon paine of Su≈øpen≈øion, deprivation, &c. and God mu≈øt haue noe ≈øolemne wor≈øhip in England except it be with communion to the ≈øame.
Ergo, To heare and communicate with the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery,
&c. is a part of divine wor≈øhip impo≈øed as a fore ≈øaide.

The fir≈øt part of the Anticedent is fals and is not proued by any ground taken from the 12. Arguments, for not man onely, but God al≈øo hath impo≈øed this Mini≈øtery, and hath appointed for the ≈øub≈øtance therof their offices & Callings of the Mini≈øters of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies; And hath required vs to communicate with them in Church Service, in that forme and manner, which the law in the true meaning therof, pre≈øcribes, & which many at the lea≈øt doe practis.

Nether doth the con≈øequent follow vpon the ≈øecond part of the Antecedent, for though humaine lawes vnder never ≈øo great puni≈øhments, ≈øhould bind vs to never ≈øo great corruptions in Gods Service; yet ≈øo lang as wee doe not actually communicate in tho≈øe corruptions, but onely in the true parts of Gods wor≈øhip, our communicating is never the wors; for the ≈øaid lawes of men, but rather the better. Nether doe wee herein ≈øtand more bound, then M. Iohn≈øon and his people doe, when they are in theis dominions: So that it makes as much again≈øt communicating with their Mini≈øtery as ours: Though therfore (as the Author of the 12. Arguments hath indevoured to proue) the Ceremonies in Controver≈øie ≈øhould be held to be a will-wor≈øhip, and therfore a ≈øin to v≈øe them in Gods wor≈øhip, yet it followeth not, by the ≈øame Argument that it is a ≈øinne, to communicate with the Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies, noe though it ≈øhould v≈øe the ≈øaid Ceremonies, much le≈ø≈øe, wher and when it v≈øeth them not, as in ≈øome places, or at ≈øome times it doth not, nether is it by law required ≈øo to doe.

div.head: THE SECOND REASON taken from the twelue Arguments. EXAMINED.

item.hi: IT is a ≈øinne again≈øt God for Chri≈øtians to pertake with the Mini≈øtery of ≈øuch, as accounting thom≈øelues to bee Servants of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, yet doe in the execution of their Mini≈øtery giue ≈øpeciall honor to Antichri≈øt, and his officers.
But the Mini≈øtery of the Church of England is ≈øuch.
Therfore it is a ≈øinne for Chri≈øtians to pertake therwith.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
Fir≈øt I deny the Propo≈øition, The true and be≈øt Mini≈øters of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, that ever were or ≈øhall bee ≈øince the Apo≈øtles, may in their ignorance, or weacknes, do ≈øome act in their Mini≈øtry, that may bring ≈øome ≈øpeciall honor to Antichri≈øt, and yet Chri≈øtians may lawfully, and without ≈øinne pertake with ≈øuch in their Mini≈øtery. It being not nece≈ø≈øary, that who ≈øoever pertaketh, with a
Mini≈øtery ≈øhould pertake al≈øo with the accidentall corruptions therof.

Hee tels vs like a bould and blind biard. That the Propo≈øition is manife≈øt and clear to any that haue an ey of Rea≈øon, and any light of divinitie ≈øhining in it. And yet it hath not ≈øo much as any colour of truth, but in the eyes of ≈øuch owles and bats as him≈øelfe is;
Arg. 2 The Propo≈øition in the twelue Arguments vnto which hee would equall and paralel his, is this, It is a ≈øinne again≈øt God, for him that is by way of excellency a Servant of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt (without a preci≈øe and directe warrant from him at any time e≈øpecially in the Solemne wor≈øhip of God) to give ≈øpeciall honour to Antichri≈øt and his members; What? mu≈øt it needs follow vpon this, That it is a ≈øinne to pertake any manner of way with ≈øuch a ones Mini≈øtery, as ≈øhall in any mea≈øure commit ≈øuch a ≈øinne? mu≈øt the joining with them in any other parts of their Mini≈øtery needs bee a communicating with them in this ≈øinne? Hee bids vs ≈øee for this 2. Cor. 6.14.17. Rev. 18.4. but what is this to the twelue Arguments, from which hee ≈øaith this rea≈øon is taken? And to what end ≈øhould wee ≈øee tho≈øe places, except hee had fir≈øt made vs to ≈øee, That our Mini≈øters in their Mini≈øtery are Infidels and Belials. That their Mini≈øtery for the ≈øub≈øtance therof is vnrighteou≈ønes and darkne≈ø≈øe. That the God wee ≈øerued in our Mini≈øtery is an Idoll, That our A≈ø≈øemblies are Babylon. And all this becau≈øe ≈øome thing happily is donne, by our Mini≈øters, which (and yet contrary to their intent) is ≈øome honour to Antichri≈øt. For except all this bee graunted vnto him, theis Texts are of noe force to confirme the Prepo≈øition.

The A≈ø≈øumption is as fals as the Propo≈øition,
Nether doth it follow from the A≈ø≈øumption, of that Argument of the 12. from which hee would ground it. For though it ≈øhould bee graunted, That to v≈øe the Ceremonies in Controver≈øie in manner and forme pre≈øcribed were to give ≈øpeciall honors to Antichri≈øt and his officers. Yet it doth not follow, That the Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies, are ≈øuch that in the execution of their Mini≈øtery giue ≈øpeciall honour to Antichri≈øt, and his officers. For ≈øome of our Mini≈øters, from whom hee ≈øeperateth, do not in the execution of their Mini≈øtery v≈øe the ≈øaid Ceremonies at any time, Nether do any of our Mini≈øters at all times in the execution therof, v≈øe them, nether are required ≈øo to doe. The A≈ø≈øumption not-with≈øtanding hee proceedeth to proue thus.

item.hi: Such a Conformitie to Antichri≈øt and his officers as is not onely be≈øids the word of God, but in a ≈øpeciall manner derogatory to all reformed Churches that haue departed from the Synagogue of Rome, is a ≈øpeciall honour to Antichri≈øt and his Officers.
But the Execution of the Mini≈øtery of the Church of Englande is ≈øuch.

p.hi: The Execution of that Mini≈øtery in manner a fore≈øaid is to giue ≈øpeciall honour to Antichri≈øt and his officers.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: The Propo≈øition is word for word in a manner taken out of the 12. Arguments. And therfore for this controver≈øie not to bee ≈øtood vpon, whether it be true, or fals.

The A≈ø≈øumption is fals, and hath noe ground at all from the 12. Argumets. For though it ≈øhould be graunted. That to v≈øe the Ceremonies in Controver≈øie in divine wor≈øhip is ≈øuch a Conformitie to Antichri≈øt, and his members, as is ≈øpecified in the Propo≈øition; yet noe man except hee haue ≈øome Crack in his braine, can from thence inferre, That the execution of our Mini≈øtery, is ≈øuch a conformitie, e≈øpecially then when in the execution therof, they doe not v≈øe the ≈øaid Ceremonies, which none doe at all times, and ≈øome doe never.

Hee proceeds to proue the A≈ø≈øumption, not by any ground taken from the 12. Arguments, but by ≈øome of the fragements of his owne former rea≈øonles rea≈øons, and therfore the maine i≈ø≈øue of the ArgumeÃÑt, lying not vpon any thing, in the ≈øaid Arguments. This ≈øecond rea≈øon of his, cannot bee ≈øaid to bee taken from the 12. Arguments. And therfore they are noe wi≈øe guilty of his ≈øchi≈øme, nor doe any wayes herein this place, patronize the ≈øame.

div.head: THE THIRD REASON TAKEN OVT OF THE TWELVE Arguments the London Mini≈øters exceptions, and the Abridgement, &c. EXAMINED.

item.hi:
IF ≈øuch bee the State of the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of England, as they are bound in their Mini≈øtration vnto ≈øuch things, as the v≈øing of them in Church Service, in manner and forme pre≈øcribed, is a will-wor≈øhip, a giving of ≈øpecially honour to Antichri≈øt and his members, a performing of honours more then Civill, even Religions, onely to a humaine power, a warranting of the like v≈øe of Iewi≈øh, Turki≈øh, Pagani≈øh or Popi≈øh ob≈øervations; a doing of Scy≈ømaticall Actions, an hauing of Spirituall Communion with Papi≈øts, in the Mi≈øteries of their Idolatry, and Super≈øtition, Amingling of prophane things with divine, an v≈øing of vnlawfull things in divine wor≈øhip; An admini≈øtring of Sacraments, that are not of divine in≈øtitution. A ≈øolemne acknowledging of Speciall homage, to the Spirituall v≈øurped authoritie of Lord Bi≈øhops, an v≈øing of humaine Traditions in Gods wor≈øhip as nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation, an apparent meanes of the damnation of many Soules. An ob≈øerving of a lieturgy
which in the wholl matter, and forms therof, is too like vnto the ma≈øse booke, &c. Then is it not lawfull to communicate with the Mini≈øters in their Mini≈øtery.
But ≈øuch is the e≈øtate of the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande.
Therfore it is not lawfull to communicate with them therin.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p:
M. Iohn≈øon thinks ≈øurely, that in this Argument hee hath out of our owne writings, for ever di≈øgraced our Mini≈øtery; But whether here or in the Arguments following, he deale faithfully with our writers, I know not, his bad dealing in this kinde, wee haue di≈øcoured in part before, and doth mo≈øt evidently appeare in one perticuler following, wherein hee mo≈øt ≈øhamfully and lewdly, as a man void of all common hone≈øty and grace, maketh the Mini≈øters of Lincolne to affirme, See pag. 98. That the Prelats are reveiled to bee great Antichri≈øts, and their Mini≈øtery, and con≈øtitution, to bee great troublers of the Church at this day, and that it cannot but bee very ≈øinfull and hurtfull, to retaine or communicate with them. The Devill him≈øelfe would haue bene a ≈øhamed in this open manner to haue tould ≈øuch a ly, and therfore hee is to bee tru≈øted, no further, then hee is ≈øeene; And herein his lewdne≈ø≈øe is the more to bee ≈øu≈øpected, That wher hee rehear≈øeth many har≈øh, bitter, and vn≈øauory ≈øpeaches again≈øt our Mini≈øtery and wor≈øhip, as written by ≈øome of our ≈øelues, that retaine communion with the Mini≈øtery, and wor≈øhip of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies; Hee doth not quote the perticuler places, but onely refers
vs to the Authors in generall, as though we had nothing els to doe, but to reede ouer wholl bookes to finde out his Allegations, or that wee mu≈øt take them vpon his word to bee faithfully reported. But let vs ≈øuppo≈øe, that our men haue ≈øo written; yet ther is noe con≈øequent in the Propo≈øition: For what if our Mini≈øtery were bound to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, to ≈øing Mattins. To wor≈øhip the Virgin Mary. To acknowledge the Popes Supremacie, &c. yet for all that it might bee lawfull to Communicate with our Mini≈øters, in their Mini≈øtery: Except that in the execution of their Mini≈øtery they ≈øubmitted vnto that which they were bound vnto. It being one thing, to bee bound, and another thing to fulfill the bonde; he might contrarily with as much witt and vnder≈øtanding haue rea≈øoned thus, If this bee the e≈øtate of the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈ø≈øemblies of Rome, that they are bound in their admini≈øtration, to the renouncing of Antichri≈øt, and all his Idolatry, offices, and will-wor≈øhip; to conforme onely, in their Mini≈øtery to the Go≈øpell of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and to ≈øuch or dinances as are agreable to the ≈øame, then it is lawfull to communicate with them in their Mini≈øtery and wor≈øhip. M. Iohn≈øon would quickly di≈øcerne the incon≈øequence of this Propo≈øition; And why? becau≈øe in the execution of their Mini≈øtery, they fulfill not this bound; And yet hee cannot deny, but that they are, by a ≈øtranger bond, even a divine bond, bounde vnto this, then our Mini≈øters to the contrary.

The con≈øequent hee ≈øaith is proued by the Mini≈øters of Lincolne≈øhire, Abridgement pag. 17. But to pa≈ø≈øe by his depraving of them before touched, noe ≈øuch matter can bee concluded from the words, which hee here citeth, yea though hee had dealt faith-fully in the citation of
them. For though it ≈øhould bee graunted that ≈øome act of ≈øpirituall fornication ≈øhould bee donne in our Mini≈øtery, That wee are to ≈øeperate from Idolators and Antichri≈øtians, and to bee as vnlike them as may bee, in their religious ob≈øervations, Though God doe beare a dete≈øtation of Idolatry, and all the Inticements therof, as vnto ≈øpeciall whoredome. Though wee ought to bee a ≈øhamed of the monuments of Idolatry, and ca≈øt them away with dete≈øtation. Though wee ≈øhould bee in ≈øome danger by them to bee corrupted in Religion, by conforming vnto Idolators in their Mini≈øtery and wor≈øhip. Though keeping communion with ≈øuch Mini≈øters ≈øhould be a ≈øpeciall meanes to harden them in their ≈øins. Though the Prelats were revealed to bee great Antichri≈øts. Though the Godly learned haue con≈øtantly taught, that Chri≈øtians are bound to for≈øake and ca≈øt of the Mini≈øtration, Ceremonies, and religious cu≈øtomes of Pagan, Iewes, Antichri≈øtian Idolators, and Hereticks, and carefully to ≈øhum all conformity with them therin; Yet it doth not therupon follow, That if the Mini≈øters of our Church A≈øsemblies bee bound as a fore≈øaid, that then it is not lawfull to communicate with them in their Mini≈øtery.
M. Iohn≈øon therfore mu≈øt bee put to this paines, To proue this con≈øequent.

For further profe of the former con≈øequent, he bringeth ≈øix Rea≈øons more out of his owne ould and fu≈øty horn of ≈øtore which proue the con≈øequent ju≈øt a baculo ad augulum. To which it ≈øhall bee needle≈ø≈øe to giue aun≈øwer, they being profes clean be≈øids the purpo≈øe of theis rea≈øons, which is to ju≈øtify their ≈øchi≈øme by grounds taken from our owne writings.
The Con≈øequent then of the Propo≈øition being evidently fals, The A≈ø≈øumption though it ≈øhould haue never ≈øo much ground from our owne writings, wil ≈øtande him in noe ≈øtead.

div.head: THE FOVRTH REASON TAKEN OVT OF THE ADMOnitions to the Parlament. EXAMINED.

item.hi: IF the Offices of Arch Bi≈øhops, Arch Deacons, Lord Bi≈øhops, Suffraces, Par≈øons, Vicars, &c. bee Antichri≈øtian and contrary to the Scriptures, then the people of God may not communicate with them in their Mini≈øtery.
The fir≈øt is true.
The later al≈øo.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: The Con≈øequent is fals, and hee goeth not about to proue it, by any thing taken out of our owne writings but by a ≈øtale profe that hath bene an≈øwered before; and therfore it requires noe an≈øwer, onely thus much of free bountie. That the offices of Arch Bi≈øhops &c. quatenes tales, are not of the e≈ø≈øence of the Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies but meere Accidents.
The A≈ø≈øumption therfore will ≈øtand him in noe ≈øteed whether it bee true or fals, and therfore I leaue it to their maintenance from whom hee ≈øaith hee borroweth it.

div.head: THE FIFT REASON TAKEN OVT OF THE offer of Conference. EXAMINED.

item.hi: IF the Propo≈øitions propounded to bee maintained in the offer of Conference bee true,
item.note: To avoid tediou≈ønes, I forbeare to ≈øet them downe as M Iohn≈øon hath done, but thou ≈øhalt di≈øcern what they are afterward in the An≈øwer.
item.hi: then is it not lawfull to heare or haue any ≈øpeciall Communion with the pre≈øent Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈øsemblies of Englande.
But tho≈øe Propo≈øitions are true.

p.hi: It is not lawfull to haue any Speciall Communion with the ≈øame.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: The Con≈øequent is fals; & doth not follow from the ≈øaid Propo≈øitions.

1. Though it ≈øhould be graunted, That all matters meerely Eccle≈øia≈øticall, lawfully impo≈øed vpon any Church are ≈øuch as may bee concluded nece≈ø≈øarily from the written word of God.
Yet in a true con≈øtituted Church ≈øome matters meerely Eccle≈øia≈øticall may bee impo≈øed through humaine frailty, that cannot ≈øo bee concluded.

2. Though, all humaine ordinances v≈øed onely or ≈øpecially in Gods wor≈øhip, whervnto they are not nece≈øsary of them≈øelues were ≈øimply vnlawfull. Yet is not every ≈øuch humaine ordinance of that nature, that it maketh the Church and Mini≈øtery wher it is v≈øed, to bee a fals Church, and Mini≈øtery, much le≈ø≈øe tho≈øe Churches, and that Mini≈øtery, wherin it is not v≈øed, but injoined onely.

3. Though it were generally graunted of all, That every true vi≈øible Church of Chri≈øt is ≈øuch a Spirituall body politick as is ≈øpecially in≈øtituted by Chri≈øt, or his Apo≈øtles in the new Te≈øtament. Yet it will not thence follow, That tho≈øe Churches, and Mini≈øteries are not to bee communicated withall, that haue any thing in or appertaining to the con≈øtitution therof not in≈øtituted by Chri≈øt; or that ≈øuch Churches are not true vi≈øible Churches.

4. Though, every true vi≈øible Church of Chri≈øt or ordinary A≈øsemblie of the faithfull, hath by Chri≈øts ordinance power in it ≈øelfe immedialy vnder Chri≈øt, to elect and ordaine, deprive and depo≈øe, their Mini≈øters, and to execute all other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Cen≈øures. Yet will it not follow from thence, That all they are fals Churches, and not to bee communicated with all. That doe not or by the lawes of man are not ≈øuffred to v≈øe that power, Nether is it ≈øure the meaning of them who offer the Conference, To maintaine, That they are no true vi≈øible Churches of Chri≈øt that cannot v≈øe that power; but are therein ≈øubject to others; for one may by Chri≈øts ordinance haue a power to doe that which yet in regard of man he hath noe power to doe.

5. Though, the Pa≈øtor of a perticuler congregation ≈øhould be yealded to bee the highe≈øt ordinary Eccle≈øia≈øticall officer in any true con≈øtituted vi≈øible Church of Chri≈øt. Yet caÃÑ it not hence bee concluded, That tho≈øe Pa≈øtors are fals Pa≈øtors, who are outwardly by mans lawes, ≈øubjected to a Superior Eccle≈øia≈øtical officer. The Father ordinary is the highe≈øt officer in the family; yet if the Magi≈øtrate ≈øubject the father in ≈øome matters appertaining to the family to another, Though therin it may bee hee may doe the father ≈øome wrong, yet doth not the father therby become a fals father, or the family a fals family. Admitte then that this prerogatiue due to Pa≈øtors, to haue noe Spirituall officers ≈øuperior vnto them, yet is it not ≈øo e≈ø≈øential vnto him, that without the Actuall v≈øe and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it, hee cannot bee a true Pa≈øtor; And yet take a true vi≈øible Church in that ≈øence, which the officers of the conference doe viz. for a perticuler ordinary A≈ø≈øembly or Congregation, And then in our owne Churches, The Pa≈øtor is the hige≈øt, ther being noe Eccle≈øia≈øticall Officer in any ≈øuch Churches, a boue him.

6. Graunt this, That it is the office of every true. Pa≈øtor to teach and Governe Spiritually one Congregation immediately vnder Chri≈øt. Can it from hence bee concluded, That they are noe true Pa≈øtors, which governe more congregations then one, or which are ≈øubject in ≈øome outward things to ≈øome others be≈øids Chri≈øt.

7. Admit, That the offices of Provinciall and dioce≈øan Bi≈øhops were contrary to the word of God; mu≈øt it needs ther vpon follow, That tho≈øe Mini≈øters, and Churches which are vnder them by the lawes of man, are fals: ≈øuch e≈øpecially who obey them onely in things which they judge
hone≈øt, and lawfull, and who vnder this ≈øubjection doe no more then they would doe, if they were not ≈øubject at all vnto the Bi≈øhops.

A man mu≈øt therfore bring a better head, & wit with him, then M. Iohn≈øons, That by the Propo≈øitions of the offer of Conference (how har≈øh ≈øoeuer they may ≈øeeme to bee) can conclude it vnlawfull to joine and communicate with our Church A≈ø≈øemblies.

For the profe of this con≈øequent he bringeth nothing out of our owne writings, but onely to giue his reader therby a vomit, ≈øome of his owne Coleworts, not twi≈øe, but twi≈øe twenty times ≈øodden; To which wee giue him leaue to looke an An≈øwer, from ≈øome as idle headded as him≈øelfe.

div.head: THE SIXT ARGVMENT TAKEN OVT OF DIvers Treati≈øes An≈øwered. This Propo≈øition being a whol leaf in his booke. I forbeare any further an≈øer downe, there being in effect little difference in the matter from that which hee hath formerly brought.

item.hi: IF the is A≈øsertious bee true, That that Church calling for which the Scripture giue noe expre≈øse warrant, is meerely v≈øurped, and vtterly vnlawfull, That as it is not lawfull to bring in any ≈øtrange doctrin, ≈øo is it not lawful, to teach the true doctrine vnder the name of any other function then is in≈øtituted by God, &c.
But the afore≈øaid A≈øsertions are true.
Therfore it is vnlawful to haue communioÃÑ with that Mini≈øtery.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: This Argument being a collection out of our writers doth not differ from the former; as him≈øelfe graunteth, and therfore needs noe further An≈øwer.
The Con≈øequent is fals, and hee proues it not by any of our owne writers, as hee ought to doe, but ≈øtil brings vs profes out of his owne mu≈øty Aumbry.
The A≈ø≈øumption therfore borrowed out of our owne writers, will doe him noe plea≈øure.

div.head: THE SEAVENTH REASON TAKEN OVT OF THE twelue Arguments viz. the tenth. EXAMINED.

item.hi: IT is a ≈øinne again≈øt Chri≈øt the ≈øole head of the Church, to haue ≈øpirituall communion with tho≈øe Mini≈øters, which in their Admini≈øtratioÃÑ of divine things do either by word or deed ≈øolemly profe≈øse and yeald a ≈øpirituall homage to an v≈øurped ≈øpirituall Authoritie in the Church.
But ≈øo do the Mini≈øters of the Church A≈øsemblies of England.

list.item: Ergo, It is a ≈øinne to haue communion with the ≈øame.

div.head: An≈øwere.
div.p: The Propo≈øition is fals; And hath noe ground from that Propo≈øition in the 12. Arguments vnto which hee would match, and forth of which hee would draw it. The Propo≈øition there is this. It is a ≈øinne again≈øt Chri≈øt, the ≈øole head of the Church, for any one of his Mini≈øters, e≈øpecially in the admini≈øtration of divine things, either by words or ≈øignes, ≈øolemly to profe≈ø≈øe, and acknowledge, a ≈øpirituall homage to a v≈øurped Sperituall authoritie in the Church. Can hee conclude his propo≈øition from this doth it hence follow, That becau≈øe our Mini≈øters in their Mini≈øtery if they conforme do in ≈øome mea≈øure in infirmitie or ignorance commit ≈øome ≈øuch ≈øinne, That therfore it is a ≈øinne to communicate with them, in other divine things, wherin they doe not commit the ≈øame ≈øinne?

Hee tels vs, That the Propo≈øition may not bee gaine-≈øaid, and why doth hee tell vs ≈øo? becau≈øe the Author of the 12. Arguments ≈øaith, his Propo≈øition may not bee denied. As though there were ju≈øt the ≈øame rea≈øon for the one as is for the other; But why may not the Propo≈øition; Becau≈øe all Spirituall power v≈øurped over the Churches of God is an Antichri≈øtian Authoritie, & to communicate with tho≈øe Mini≈øters which Profe≈ø≈øe Spirituall homage therunto, is to communicate which ≈øuch as profe≈øse Spirituall homage to Antichri≈øt, which mu≈øt needs bee a ≈øinne again≈øt Chri≈øt the head of the Church. A deepe and learned Rea≈øon. It can bee no ≈øinne again≈øt Chri≈øt, to communicate with them, which in ≈øome action profe≈ø≈øe Spirituall homage to Antichri≈øt, except in their communion, they al≈øo profe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame homage, which like an ignorant di≈øputant, hee maketh noe
que≈øtion of. As though to joine with one, that doth evill, in that which is good, is alwaies to joine with him in the evill, as though to joine with a glutton in eating nece≈ø≈øary food, were to joine with him in his gluttony, or to joine with a bla≈øphemer, in the act of his bla≈øpheming in re≈øcuing an inocent out of the hands of Robbers, were to communicate with him in his bla≈øphemy; But herein hee propounds onely to play the Ape imitating the Author of the twelue Arguments, who ≈øaith his Propo≈øition may not bee gaine ≈øaid, Becau≈øe all Spirituall Power v≈øurped over the Churches of God, is an Antichri≈øtian Authority, and to profe≈øse ≈øpirituall homage thervnto, is to profe≈ø≈øe ≈øpirituall homage vnto Antichri≈øt, which mu≈øt needs bee a ≈øinne. But what? is there no more Rea≈øon in this rea≈øon then in his? If this bee a good Argument to proue that Propo≈øition for which it is brought, mu≈øt his Argument needs, bee as good to proue his propo≈øition? what becau≈øe it is a ≈øinne to profe≈øse Speciall homage vnto Antichri≈øt mu≈øt it needs al≈øo bee a ≈øinne, to communicate al≈øo with them, who do profe≈øse ≈øome homage vnto Antichri≈øt, what? to communicate with them in other matters?

The A≈ø≈øumption is as fals as the Propo≈øition, And hath noe ground for the twelue Arguments, for though it were graunted, That to v≈øe the controverted ceremonies in manner and forme pre≈øcribed were even in the ≈øolemne wor≈øhip of Chri≈øt by ≈øolemne ≈øignes to acknowledge a ≈øpirituall homage to a ≈øpirituall v≈øurped Authority of Arch Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops. Yet doth it not ther-from follow, That our Mini≈øters in the admini≈øtration of divine things, doe the ≈øame; for none of our Mini≈øters do alwaies in the admini≈øtration of divine things profe≈ø≈øe any ≈øuch homage, and ≈øome do
never profe≈ø≈øe it. And tho≈øe who profe≈ø≈øe it, when they doe profe≈ø≈øe it, propound, and intend noe ≈øuch matter.
Hee proues the A≈ø≈øumption, Thus

They preach the word and admini≈øter the Sacraments by virtue of their calling receaved from the Arch-Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, &c. The vanity wherof hath bene ≈øufficiently ≈øhewed all-ready hee therin begging one of his ≈øtale rea≈øons, and not borrowing any thing, from the twelue Arguments. That which followeth, wherby hee would proue, That the Authority of L. Arch-Bi≈øhops, and Bi≈øhops is v≈øurped, which he makes the 2. parts of his A≈ø≈øumption; is altogether idle, and to noe purpo≈øe, and donne onely of malice to the Author of the twelue Arguments for otherwi≈øe, had hee intended herein the convincing of the ≈øaid Author, and of them which are of his minde, (which is the onely v≈øe of the later ≈øort of his rea≈øons, & which can ≈øerve for noe other v≈øe) it had bene ≈øufficient to haue produced his A≈ø≈øertion without his profes; for that had bene enough to declare, The Authors conceit.

Hee concludes crowing as if hee were ≈øome Cock of the game, that had picked out the eyes and broken the necks of al that haue bene ≈øet again≈øt him. And thus (≈øaith hee) the cau≈øe is yealded by them≈øelues. And is it not (thinke wee) finely yealded? is it not a feild ≈øtoutly wonne, Is it any mervaille, that hee makes ≈øuch out cries again≈øt the wholl Chri≈øtian world, that will not follow ≈øuch a leader.

But I leaue him to his vaine conceits of his owne cau≈øe, Tru≈øting that any ≈øober and judicious Chri≈øtian, will bee able to di≈øcerne, therin his fond and ignorant
vanity. And wher as in the An≈øwer of his Rea≈øons, I haue omitted to an≈øwer to many perticuler pa≈ø≈øages. All things con≈øidered I ≈øhall not neede to aske him pardon, I ≈øhould rather haue cau≈øe to expect thanks, if I had to deale with a rea≈øonable and good natured adver≈øary.

div.head: REASONS OR ARGVMENTS, TENDING TO PROVE THAT IT IS A ≈øinne to ≈øeperate from the publique Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈ø≈øemblies of Englande.

head.hi: DIRECTLY CONTRARY TO Mr. IONHSONS OWNE Rea≈øons.

div.head: AND VSVALLY IN THAT REgard made in the ≈øame moode and figure.
The fir≈øt Argument.
div.p:
It is a ≈øinne to ≈øeperate from that Mini≈øtery which is
≈øet by Chri≈øt in his Church for the worke of his Mini≈øterie.
But ≈øuch is the Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈ø≈øemblies of England.
Therfore it is a ≈øinne to ≈øeperate from it.
The profes which he bringeth to confirme the maine Propo≈øition of his fir≈øt Rea≈øon, will ≈øerue to proue this.

list.item: The A≈ø≈øumption may bee proued thus.
The Mini≈øtery of true Pa≈øtors and Teachers is the Mini≈øtery which is ≈øet by Chri≈øt in his Church.
The Mini≈øtery afore≈øaid is the Mini≈øtery of true Pa≈øtors and Teachers.
Therfore it is a Mini≈øtery ≈øet by Chri≈øt in his Church.

div.p: The Propo≈øition is his owne.
The A≈ø≈øumption I proue thus.
The Mini≈øtery which hath in it all things e≈ø≈øentiall to the office & calling of true Pa≈øtors & Teachers is the Mini≈øtery of true Pa≈øtors and Teachers.
But ≈øuch is our Mini≈øtery.
Therfore it is the Mini≈øtery of true Pa≈øtors and Teachers.
I think he is not ≈øo ≈øimple as to deny the Propo≈øition.
The A≈ø≈øumption is proued thus.

To haue ≈øuch gifts as Chri≈øt a≈øcended to heauen to giue for the worke of his Mini≈øtery. To bee outwardly called to that worke by ≈øuch a Church as profe≈ø≈øeth the fondamentall points of the Go≈øpell. To in≈øtruct the people committed to their Charge, in the doctrine of the law and Go≈øpell: To admini≈øter vnto them the holy Sacraments of Chri≈øt, And
to bee their month in prayer vnto God; Are all things e≈ø≈øentially appertaining to the office of true Pa≈øtors and Teachers.
Such is the Mini≈øtery of our A≈ø≈øemblies.
Therfore it is the true Mini≈øtery of Pa≈øtors and Teachers.
If hee deny the Propo≈øition, hee mu≈øt ≈øhew, what other matters do e≈ø≈øentially appartaine vnto their calling which yet hee hath not donne.

For confirmation of the A≈ø≈øumption it ≈øhall bee ≈øufficient that wee can ≈øet forth vnto him, ≈øuch a Mini≈øtery in ≈øundry of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies, of which all thei≈øe points may bee truely verified, their conformitie to the State, and their ≈øinne therin (if any bee) not with≈øtanding.

div.head: The ≈øecond Argument.
div.p: The Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies is not the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
Therfore it is a ≈øinne to ≈øeperate from the ≈øame.
The con≈øequent mu≈øt bee true vntill hee can bring forth any other exceptions again≈øt our Mini≈øtery then ≈øuch as appertaine to the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
The A≈ø≈øumption is proued thus.
The Mini≈øtery of the Church A≈ø≈øemblies of Antichri≈øt is of Prie≈øts and Deacons.
But the Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies is not the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts and Deacons.
Therfore it is not the Mini≈øtery of Antichri≈øts Apo≈øta≈øie.
The Propo≈øition is his owne.
The A≈ø≈øumption if I ≈øhould follow his learning, I might proue thus, The Mini≈øtery of true Pa≈øtors, and Teachers is not the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts and Deacons.

But ≈øuch is the Mini≈øtery of our A≈ø≈øemblies. Ergo, and for the profe of the A≈ø≈øumption, I might ≈øend him back againe to my fir≈øt Argument. But I wil leaue ≈øuch a kind of di≈øputing to him≈øelf, as his owne peculier, and proue it otherwi≈øe thus.

list.item: That Mini≈øtery which in the maine and e≈ø≈øentiall faculties, & offices therof, is oppo≈øite to the maine, and e≈ø≈øential faculties, functions & offices of Prie≈øts, and Deacons is not the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts, and Deacons.
But ≈øuch is our Mini≈øtery.
Therfore it is not the Mini≈øtery of Prie≈øts and Deacons.

div.p: The Propo≈øition is vndeniable.
The A≈ø≈øumption may bee proued thus.

list.item: That Mini≈øtery which is oppo≈øite to the Sacrafice of the Ma≈ø≈øe, is oppo≈øite to the maine and e≈ø≈øentiall faculties, functions and offices of Prie≈øts and Deacons.
Such is our Mini≈øtery.
Therfore it is oppo≈øite to the maine and e≈ø≈øentiall faculties of Prie≈øts and Deacons.

div.p: I doe not ≈øee, which of theis Premi≈øes hee can with any colourable rea≈øon deny. I will therfore for beare to proceed further in this Argument: vntill I ≈øee what hee can ≈øay again≈øt it.

div.head: The third Argument.
div.p: That Mini≈øtery which profe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øt by maintaining his covenant with the ≈øeales of it, doth directly and profe≈ø≈øedly warre again≈øt the Bea≈øt and again≈øt all that wor≈øhip his Image, and receave his marke in their forehead and hand, cannot without ≈øin bee ≈øeperated from.
Such is our Mini≈øtery.
Therfore it caÃÑnot without ≈øin be ≈øeperated from.
The Propo≈øition is true. For noe Mini≈øtery ≈øo profe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øt, but the true Mini≈øtery of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, doth directly and profe≈ø≈øedly warre in manner, & forme afore≈øaide.
The A≈ø≈øumption I proue thus.

list.item: That Mini≈øtery which ≈øo profe≈ø≈øing oppo≈øeth it ≈øelf profe≈ø≈øedly to the Pope of Rome as that great Antichri≈øt, which directly and expre≈øly renounceth all Eccle≈øia≈øticall homage vnto him, or any of his profe≈ø≈øed cleargie, That denieth and di≈øputeth again≈øt (mo≈øt effectually) all the maine and foundamentall points of Popery, which oppo≈øeth it ≈øelfe to the vttermo≈øt of the ≈øtrength and Power therof, to all the profe≈ø≈øed frends of the Pope, and Church of Rome, That houldeth and maintaineth all the members therof to bee hereticks and Idolators, and in the ≈øtate of condemnation, and ≈øuch as no good Chri≈øtian ought to coÃÑmunicate ≈øpiritually withall, That Mini≈øtery (I ≈øay) doth directly warre again≈øt the bea≈øt, and again≈øt al that wor≈øhip his Image, &c.
But all this is donne in and by our Mini≈øtery.
Therefore it doth directly, and profe≈ø≈øedly warre again≈øt the Bea≈øt, &c.

div.p: I know not which of theis Propo≈øitions hee can with any face deny; but deny either when hee will, I ≈øhall bee readie to proue them.

div.head: The fourth Argument.
div.p: That Mini≈øtery which, deriveth the power and functions therof from Chri≈øt cannot without ≈øinne bee ≈øeperated from.

list.item: The Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies deriveth the Power and functions therof from Chri≈øt.
Therfore it cannot without ≈øinne bee ≈øeperated from.

div.p: The profes of the maine propo≈øition of this fourth Argument will ≈øerue to proue this Propo≈øition.
The A≈ø≈øumptioÃÑ is as ≈øufficiently proued by my third and fir≈øt Argument as his contrary, is by his third and fir≈øt. But I further proue it thus.

list.item: If the Power and functions of our Mini≈øtery for the ≈øub≈øtance therof, bee the very ≈øame, for which Chri≈øt a≈øcended vp into Heaven to procure for the edification of his body the Church, then doth it for the ≈øub≈øtance therof, derive the Power and functions therof from Chri≈øt.
But the fir≈øt is true, therfore the later is true al≈øo.

div.p: The Con≈øequent of the Propro≈øition is vndeniable.
The A≈ø≈øumption is as vndeniable, Except hee can ≈øhew any ≈øub≈øtantiall difference betweene the one and the other.

div.head: The fift Argument.

list.item: That Mini≈øtery which worketh vpon the Con≈øciences of men, by a true ≈øpirituall calling cannot without ≈øinne bee ≈øeperated from.
Such is our Mini≈øtery.
Therfore it cannot without ≈øinne bee ≈øeperated from.

div.p: The Propo≈øition cannot bee gaine ≈øaid.
The A≈ø≈øumption is proued by my 2. Argument, but I further proue it in this manner.

list.item: That Mini≈øtery which worketh vpon the Con≈øciences of men onely by a ≈øpirituall gift and grace giuen by Chri≈øt, and directed by the word of God, doth worke vpon the con≈øciences of men by a true Spirituall calling.
Theis doth the Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies.
Therfore it worketh vpoÃÑ the con≈øciences of men by a true Spirituall calling.

div.p: The truth of either of theis Propo≈øitions, I ≈øhal ea≈øily proue, if they bee deinde.

div.head: The ≈øixt Argument.

list.item: The Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies is noe ≈øtrang Mini≈øtery.
Therfore it is a ≈øinne to ≈øeperate from it.

div.p: This Anticedent is better proued by my fir≈øt Argument: then his contrary A≈ø≈øumption is by his fir≈øt Argument. I proue it not with≈øtanding thus.

list.item:
That Mini≈øtery which for the ≈øub≈øtance therof, was practized by Chri≈øt, the Apo≈øtles many worthy
and famous Martyrs and witne≈ø≈øes of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt in Church A≈ø≈øemblies is no ≈øtrange Mini≈øtery.
Such is our Mini≈øtery for the ≈øub≈øtance therof.
Therfore it is no ≈øtrange Mini≈øtery.

div.p: Surely hee will never deny the Propo≈øition.
Nether can hee deny the A≈ø≈øumption, except he can ≈øhew a Sub≈øtantiall difference, between the Mini≈øteries afore≈øaide.

div.head: The ≈øeaventh Argument.

list.item: That Mini≈øtery which is from Heauen cannot without ≈øinne bee ≈øeperated from.
The Mini≈øtery of our Church A≈ø≈øemblies is from Heaven.
Therfore it caÃÑnot without ≈øinne be ≈øeperated froÃÑ.

div.p: The Propo≈øition is plaine.
The A≈ø≈øumption is proued by all the former Arguments, which in his logick Scholes, in his owne cau≈øe is profe good enough. But I ad a further profe.

list.item: That Mini≈øtery which in all the parts and Power therof is principally excercized and directed, to bring men to Heaven is a Mini≈øtery from Heaven.
Such is our Mini≈øtery afore≈øaid.
Therfore it is from Heaven.

div.p: The Propo≈øition is firme. It being not po≈ø≈øible, that that Mini≈øtery which is from Earth or hell ≈øhould bee principally directed and excercized in all the parts and Powers therof to bring men to Heaven.
The A≈ø≈øumption may not bee denied, except hee can ≈øhew in what other thing it is more principally excercized, and to what other end, directed, which hee can never doe.

div.head: AN ANSWER TO CERTAINE DEMANDES OFTEN PVBLISHED by M. Iohn≈øon, the deciding wherof (as hee ≈øaith) will end the controver≈øies between him and vs.
The fir≈øt Demande.
div.p: WHether the Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt haue by his la≈øt will and Te≈øtament, given vnto and ≈øet in his Church, ≈øufficient ordinarie officers, with their calling, worke and maintenance: for the admini≈øtration of his holy things, and for the ≈øufficient ordinarie in≈øtruction, guidance and ≈øervice of his Church, to the end of the worlde.

1 I An≈øwer directly (vnder≈øtanding by Officers, ≈øpirituall officers) that hee hath; And that it is a Sinne herein to breake his will and te≈øtament, ether by depriving the Church of any of tho≈øe officers, or by bringing into it any other
kinde, with any other kinde of calling, or worke, then hee hath appointed in the ≈øame.

2. That not with≈øtanding this, the Civill Magi≈øtrate hath power, to ≈øet over the Churches of Chri≈øt in his Dominions, Commi≈ø≈øioners and over≈øeers, which are not ≈øpecially appointed by Chri≈øt in his Te≈øtament, civilly to guide & gouerne the Churches, & to maintaine tho≈øe priviledges, liberties, offices & orders, that Chri≈øt hath endowed them with all, again≈øt all the enemies, both without and within the ≈øame.

3. Concerning the maintenaunce of the Mini≈øters: Chri≈øt hath ≈øet downe no more in his Te≈øtament, then this in effect, That the labourer is worthie of his hire: And that for their Mini≈øtration of Spirituall things, the Churches that enjoy their labours, ought to Mini≈øter to them, of their Temporals. But after what e≈øpeciall manner, they ≈øhall be maintained, he hath (for ought appeareth yet to the contrary) ether left it to the di≈øcretion of the Churches, if they haue the free di≈øpo≈øition of their temporall goods in their owne hand: or of the Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrate, who in ≈øuch ca≈øes may ≈øee what is fitter, then the Churches them≈øelues.

div.head: The ≈øecond Demande.
div.p:
Whether the Offices of Pa≈øtors, Teachers, Elders, Deacons and Helpers, be tho≈øe offices appointed by Chri≈øt in his Te≈øtament before ≈øaid? Or whether the pre≈øent eccle≈øia≈øticall offices of Arch-Bi≈øhops, Lord-Bi≈øhops, Suffraganes, Deanes, Prebendaries, Cannons, Pettie Cannons, Prie≈øts, Deacons, Arch-Deacons,
Doctors of Divinitie, Chaplins or Hou≈øe-Prie≈øts, Commi≈ø≈øaries, Officials, Proctors, Apparitors, Par≈øons, Vicars, Curats, Vagrant or Mercenary, Preachers, Church-wardens, Sidemen, Clarkes, Sextons. and the re≈øt now had in the Cathedrall and peri≈øhionall A≈ø≈øemblies, bee tho≈øe offices oppointed by Chri≈øt in his Te≈øtament, as is afore≈øaid or no?

1. I graunt, that the Offices in the fir≈øt place mentionned, are tho≈øe very offices which Chri≈øt hath appointed that there is no Church of Chri≈øt, but hath v≈øe and need of them; And that ≈øuch are ≈øomeway defective, that want any one of them.

2.
