That yet not with≈øtanding, they may bee true Churches, that want ≈øome of them; yea the chiefe≈øt of them, as thos A≈ø≈øemblies of our owne profe≈ø≈øion in England, haue for many yeares (as I take it) bin without, ether all or chiefe≈øt of them; And yet they judge them≈øelues true Churches: yea, though they haue not ≈øo much as the Sacraments admini≈øtred among≈øt them.

3. Where the Civill Magi≈øtrate doth his dutie as hee ought: and where the Churches haue the benifit of his help, for the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of ≈øinne, and the relieving of the poor, and tho≈øe that are in any di≈øtres (which the Apo≈øtolicall Churches wanted) there the want of ≈øome of theis offices, may bee the better borne with all: and the Church le≈ø≈øe defective, that doth want them, e≈øpecially the two latter.

4. I graunt that none of tho≈øe offices here mentioned in the latter part (excepting that of Deacons,) are in name tho≈øe offices which Chri≈øt hath appointed: ≈øome of them, nether in name, nor in deed: ≈øome in deed,
though not in name; Some haue the name of that, which indeed they are not; Some though they bee ≈øet over the Churches: Yet are not indeed any proper offices of the Church; Some offices here named nether in deed nor name, as they are ≈øuch, are eccle≈øia≈øtical offices, but onely ≈øchoole Titles and dignities giuen to men eminent in learning, for incouragement of others to ≈øtudy good letters, e≈øpecially divinitie.

5. All the offices appointed by Chri≈øt to bee in his Church‚ñ™ to the end of the world, in effect and ≈øub≈øtance may be found conteined vnder ≈øome of theis, though ≈øomwhat di≈øgui≈øed with ≈øtrange names, borrowed from the Church of Rome: and the principall & mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, are vnder ≈øome of theis. For many of theis which you di≈øpitfully cal, mercenary Preachers, Prie≈øts, Hou≈øe-Prie≈øts: yea, Par≈øons, Vicars, Curats, are in very deed and truth, in office & practice (what≈øoever they are in name) The very Pa≈øtors and Teachers, that Chri≈øt hath ordained, mini≈øtring in his Churches, according to their places and callings: And tho≈øe gifts which Chri≈øt had be≈øtowed vpon them al, the ordinary meanes of ≈øalvation. As for theis varitie of names, mo≈øt of them ari≈øe, from that varitie of maintenance that is in our Churches, and not of their ≈øpirituall offices; So that in this manner to di≈øpute again≈øt our Churches, becau≈øe the Mini≈øters therof, haue ≈øuch & ≈øuch names, is: as though one ≈øhould di≈øpute again≈øt the Church of the Iewes in Chri≈øts time and haue denied communion with it, asking; whether Prie≈øts, Levites, and Prophets, were not tho≈øe officers which God had appointed to governe the Church of the Iewes with all? Or whether Scribes, Phari≈øies, Saduces,
Captaines of the Temple, Rulers of the Synagogues, Doctors of the Law, Centurions, Souldiers, the high-Prie≈øts Servants, &c. were tho≈øe Officers? Or as if one di≈øputing again≈øt your owne Churches, or tho≈øe which haue (though not ≈øo fully, as you would haue them) interteined the ≈øame di≈øcipline with you, ≈øhould: to warrant their ≈øeperation from you, & their condemnation of you as fal≈øe Churches, move the very ≈øame que≈øtion in nature vnto you; Asking you whether Pa≈øtors, Teachers, Elders, Deacons & Helpers, be not tho≈øe Offices, which Chri≈øt hath appointed in his Te≈øtament: Or whether Schi≈ømaticks, Refractaries, lay-Aldermen; Pari≈øh Bi≈øhops, Con≈øi≈øtorians, Pari≈øh Popes, Proctors of ≈øpitle hou≈øes, Dawbers, Thackers, Tailers, Tinkers, &c. be tho≈øe Officers? for thus it hath plea≈øed ≈øome, to put theis odious names vpon tho≈øe, which bearre & exerci≈øe the offices of Pa≈øtors, Teachers, Elders, &c.

div.head: The third Demande.
div.p: Whether the callings and entrance into the eccle≈øia≈øticall offices afore≈øaid, their admini≈øtration and maintenance, now had and retained in England, bee the manner of calling, admini≈øtration and maintenance, which Chri≈øt hath appointed, for the Offices of the Church, aboue named, or no?

Not to ≈øtand (for the avoiding of multiplicity of vnne≈ø≈øarie que≈øtions) vpon defence of the calling, entrance, admini≈øtration and maintenaunce of all; I aun≈øwer directly and plainly, That the Calling, entraunce, admini≈øtration and maintenance, of many
(at the lea≈øt) that are called into eccle≈øia≈øticall offices, is in very effect and ≈øub≈øtance the ≈øame, that Chri≈øt hath appointed. They are men in≈øtructed in the knowledge of good Letters, e≈øpecially in divinitie. They haue a gift in ≈øome good mea≈øure, to devide the word of God, according to the nece≈ø≈øities of the people, over whom they are ≈øet. They haue a de≈øire, to do Chri≈øt and his Church ≈øervice in his Mini≈øtrie, and a purpo≈øe to giue them≈øelues over vnto that worke. They haue in ≈øome good mea≈øure, (for none hath them in perfection) all tho≈øe graces and gifts that Paul to Timothie, requires to bee in Bi≈øhops and Elders; They are ≈øo judged and e≈øteemed to bee of other Mini≈øters, and well grounded Chri≈øtians, and of tho≈øe people which ≈øubmit vnto their Mini≈øtrie, who accepting of them and their Mini≈øtrie as ≈øent of God, de≈øiring and yealding them≈øelues to liue vnder them, as is fitting for Chri≈øtians: And they re≈øolving to guide and governe them, as becometh ≈øpirituall leaders and guides; Such calling and entraunce as this, haue many of our Church-officers; more then this in ≈øub≈øtance and effect, is not appointed by Chri≈øt. Tho≈øe defects and errors which over and be≈øides, many time; they yeald vnto in their calling, entraunce and admini≈øtration, are not of that nature and qualitie, that they make anullitie thereof, or make it a fals, and Antichri≈øtian calling, entrance or admini≈øtration. The maintenance they liue by, as it is no where in ≈øpeciall appointed of Chri≈øt: ≈øo is it no where in generall, or ≈øpeciall forbidden; In the yealding wher-of vnto the Mini≈øters, they fulfill the Te≈øtament of Chri≈øt, in giving of their temporall things, for ≈øpirituall, in giving hire to the
Labourers, &c. and do not therin breake any parts els therof, hee having no where forbiden, any ≈øuch manner of maintenance, but left it indifferent, to giue money or fruits, In fruits to giue the twentith, the twelfth, the tenth, the eighth of the increa≈øe, according ether to their e≈øtate, or the nece≈ø≈øitie of the Mini≈øters, wherein the Magi≈øtrate hath authority to rule and define, who hath in his hand, the power of mens temporall e≈øtates; or the Church, if the Magi≈øtrate leaue vnto them, the free v≈øe of their owne Temporalties; Nether is the tenth required to be giuen by the Magi≈øtrate, or yealded to bee given by the Church, to the maintenaince of the Mini≈øters, any more ceremoniall or Iudaicall, in regard of the number, then in regard of the matter; Nether did their any Mini≈øtery, lie ≈øo much in the quantity of the thing given, as in the very gift and offering it ≈øelfe; So that by the ≈øame rea≈øon, that you make it vnlawfull, for Mini≈øters to be maintained by tithes, you make it vnlawfull for them, to haue any kinde of maintenaunce from the Church, there having bin a Ceremonie, in the very matter it ≈øelf, as much as in the quantitie, or number. For not onely their giving the tithe of their increa≈øe, but al≈øo the very giving of their increa≈øe it ≈øelfe, out of that con≈øideration, was ceremoniall.

div.head: The fourth Demande.
div.p:
Whether every true vi≈øible Church of Chri≈øt, bee not a companie of people called and ≈øeperated out from the worlde, and the fals wor≈øhip and waies therof, by the word of God: and joined together in the
fellow≈øhip of the Go≈øpell, by voluntarie profe≈ø≈øion of the faith, and obedience of Chri≈øt?
I an≈øwer, 1. That every true vi≈øible Church of Chri≈øt is ≈øuch a people.

2. That yet, not with≈øtanding they bee ≈øuch; they may in their infirmitie and ignorance, walke in ≈øome of the waies, and practice ≈øome parts of the fals wor≈øhip of the world, not with≈øtanding their ≈øaid ≈øeperation, conjunction and profe≈ø≈øion.

3. They may in time become, the true vi≈øible Churches of Chri≈øt, which at the fir≈øt were not, in the ≈øaid manner and forme, called, ≈øeperated and joined together, but forced and con≈øtrained again≈øt their will by the ≈øword of the Magi≈øtrate. 4. Many of tho≈øe Churches in our kingdome from which you ≈øeperate, as they now ≈øtand, are ≈øuch a companie of people, ≈øo called, ≈øeperated and joined together: though in all three, there may bee ≈øome kinde of defects and wants.

div.head: The fift Demande.
div.p: Whether the Sacraments, being the ≈øeales of righteou≈ønes which is by faith, may be admini≈øtred vnto any other, but to the faithfull and their feed: or in any other Mini≈øtrie, or maÃÑner then is appointed by Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the Apo≈øtle and high Prie≈øt of our profe≈ø≈øion? And whether they be no otherwi≈øe admini≈øtred, in our Cathedrall & Pari≈øhionall Churches in England.
1. I graunt, that the Sacraments ought to bee admini≈øtred, onely to the faithfull in outward profe≈ø≈øion, and their ≈øeed, and in no other Mini≈øtrie, or manner, then is appointed by Chri≈øt.

2. In many of our Churches (at the lea≈øt) they are admini≈øtred in no other manner, from and by no other Mini≈øtry, then Chri≈øt hath appointed: nor to no other per≈øons. 3. Every error and defect, in ≈øome part of the matter, and forme, and mini≈øtrie, a ri≈øing of ignorance, or infirmity, maketh not the Churches fals Churches; except you hould, That no true perticuler Church can erre, which is a more gro≈ø≈øe opinion, then that of the Papi≈øts.

div.head: The ≈øixt Demande.
div.p: Whether the booke of Common Praier, with the fea≈øts, fa≈øts, holy daies, ≈øtinted Praiers & liturgie pre≈øcribed therin, & v≈øed in theis A≈ø≈øemblies, be the true wor≈øhip of God, commaunded in his word: or the deui≈øe & invention of man, for Gods wor≈øhip & ≈øervice.

1. Though it ≈øhould bee graunted, that the booke of Common praier in all the parts and percels therof, is not the true wor≈øhip of God, but containeth in it ≈øome devi≈øes and inventions of man; yet, the true wor≈øhip of God (not with≈øtanding) is pre≈øcribed in it.
2. So much of it as is v≈øed in many of our Churches, is the true wor≈øhip of God, and in effect commanded in his word.

Tho≈øe devi≈øes and inventions of men, with the fea≈øts, fa≈øts & holy daies therin pre≈øcribed, though they ≈øhould be graunted, to be ≈øinnes and corruptions in our Churches, & ≈øuch as ought not to be conformed vnto: & ≈øuch as we ought rather to ≈øeperate froÃÑ our Churches then ether by ≈øub≈øcription, conformity, or any other meanes, to approue; yet are they not of that nature, that

div.head: The ≈øeaventh Demande.
div.p: Whether all people and Churches without exception, be not bound in Religion onely, to receive and ≈øubmit vnto that Mini≈øtry, wor≈øhip and order, which Chri≈øt as Lord and King, hath given and appointed to his Church? Or whether any may receiue & joine vnto another devi≈øed by man, for the ≈øervice of God? And con≈øequently, whether they that joine to the pre≈øent eccle≈øia≈øticall Mini≈øtery, wor≈øhip and order of the Cathedrall, and Pari≈øhionall A≈ø≈øemblies, can bee a≈ø≈øured by the word of God, that they joine to the former ordained by Chri≈øt, and not to the latter devi≈øed by man, even the man of ≈øinne, for the wor≈øhip and ≈øervice of God?
1. I graunt that wee are bound in Religion, to do that which is ≈øpecified in the fir≈øt part of your que≈øtion.

2. To joine with our ecclea≈øiia≈øticall Mini≈øtrie, wor≈øhip and orders (at lea≈øt in tho≈øe A≈ø≈øemblies, whether Cathedrall or other, when and where all things are not performed, according to the rigour of our lawes) is not to joine with a Mini≈øtrie and wor≈øhip, devi≈øed by that man of ≈øinne: but (though not in all the ≈øpecialties and formalities therof) with ≈øuch a Mini≈øtrie and wor≈øhip, as is required and in≈øtituted of God.

3. They which joine to the pre≈øent eccle≈øia≈øticall Mini≈øtrie,
wor≈øhip and order of the Cathedral or Pari≈øhionall A≈ø≈øemblies in tho≈øe things which are performed therein, according to the true intent and meaning of our lawes, though ≈øome things bee done not warrantable by the word: yet they may bee a≈ø≈øured by the word of God, that they joine to the ≈øub≈øtance of that Mini≈øtrie, wor≈øhip and order, which Chri≈øt as Lord & King, hath given and appointed to his Church; At lea≈øt they may bee as well a≈ø≈øured therof by Gods word, as any that joine with the pre≈øent eccle≈øia≈øticall Mini≈øtery, wor≈øhip and order of the A≈ø≈øemblies of tho≈øe of the Seperation, can bee a≈ø≈øured by the ≈øame word, that they joine to that forme, which is ordained by Chri≈øt.
